description:
The Black Horse might be my new favorite place in the world! I was in SF   solo for a work trip and it happened to be my birthday. A couple of amazing coworkers were also in town so we decided to get saucy. We ended up at Black Horse and we had an absolute blast. Check out Jonathan T's review for a full account of what went down. 

This magical night was filled with bathtub beers, new friends, bar dancing, ice throwing, dice rolling, and even hula hooping! I got to shotgun a beer, wear a happy birthday sign the bartender cut down from the ceiling, and don her dope ass LA Gear pink denim jacket while I showed off my moves atop the bar. The memories I have are all amazing and I can't wait to come back on my next visit.
author: Scotty C.

description:
The most wild, scandalous, and this-stays-only-between-us-please memorable bar experience of life occurred in space no larger than a 2010 Toyota Camry (LX). Why? 

- I won a dice game of 1, 4, 24. (Buy-ins cost one dollar). And after I announced my victory, the bartender dropped all ten, hepatitis covered dollar bills on my face. When she ran out of money, she tossed a stack of coasters onto me. #blessed

- If the bartender likes a patron, he or she may ask that person to dance on top of the bar. I had the opportunity to do so and got down to Michael Jackson (so stretch your calves and ankles before venturing out to The Black Horse). Also, if you stand on the bar you then the awesome opportunity to have ice thrown at you. *Pro tip: Hold onto one of the walls, so you don't fall. 

- It ain't up to code, but all of the beer sits in a bathtub full of ice behind the bar, and their selection varies every night. Bring cash because they don't take credit card. *Note: The convenient store on the corner has an ATM. 

- I saw my boy Scottie grind with the bartender. He asked for her pink jean jacket, so she sexily took it off, rubbed it in between her cooch, and handed it to him between her legs. He then put it on and looked mighty fly. They then danced together, and he looked so happy because the sista was stacked. She's pregnant now. 

- The bathroom has one magazine (ESPN), and it's from 2005. The cover page features ex-NFL running back Cedric Benson and words that read, "I'M NOT RICKY." I don't think anyone has touched it since that year, too. 

- A random happy birthday sign ran across the room, and the bartender cut down just for Scotty.

- Slam a beer for only six bucks. 

- For about ten minutes, everyone left the bar to practice hula hooping out on the sidewalk.

- There was a dude hugging a Taylor Swift cardboard cutout and taking selfies with it. lol. 

Sure, I may have contracted some sort of venereal disease or skin infection that night, but I would relive it all over again. The Black Horse welcomed me to its cozy, bacteria infested little home, and I can't wait to return see my weird family. And I wouldn't want it any other way.  

Wear shoes you don't love there. Trust.
author: Jonathan T.

description: We were walking back to our hotel and someone inside this tiny little bar yells at us to come in and that this is the "smallest bar west of the Mississippi".  We decided to stop in and grab a beer and we were glad we did.  Very charming local watering hole, super friendly staff and patrons, and rotating selection of craft beers kept behind the bar in an old bathtub full of ice.  Worth checking out!
author: Mark Y.

description:
This bar rocks. And I'm not just saying that because, thanks to 1-4-24,* I've almost always walked out of this bar with more money than I walked in with. 

It's really more like hanging out at a friend's place than a bar. It's tiny, just like all my friend's apartments. 

James is less like a bartender and more like my buddy who's just standing closer to the bathtub of beers, so he hands me one when I'm in need. I do have to pay him (and tip him) for those beers, but just like most of my friends, he's tossing them back too. Occasionally he'll just shotgun one because sipping is too slow. 

And just like most of my friends' places, we all want to leave when Ruggy shows up. 

Beer and cash only.
____________

*This is literally the only game I have ever been lucky at. I don't understand it, but I also don't want to question. If you don't know what 1-4-24 is, you better get over to the Black Horse and find out.
author: Peter D.

description:
Insanely small with all the charm of someplace ten times its size. The Black Horse London Pub is another oddity I check off my list of strange-yet-cool places I've visited in San Francisco. 

The size is what makes it unique and is also their selling point. The tiny bar can seat maybe eight people max. When sitting, your back is practically up against the wall. Your knees bump the bar. The stools are uncomfortable. The beer is literally a few canned selections served out of a bathtub. 

If all this sounds horrible, it's not. It's what makes this place fun. You can actually get to know your neighbors without shoving your way through crowds or getting mean mugged. It's small enough that the bartender will stop and talk to you. And on a good night, like the Tuesday I visited, they might even have a couple drunk dudes crammed in the back corner playing guitar.
author: Alex L.

description:
It's like I'm starring in, "Being John Malkovich" as the place is so amazingly small. Stumbled into the Black Horse last night with a friend on a whim and really enjoyed my time there. For those of you who don't know, the beers are in a bathtub behind the bar, the place might seat 10 and it's an great no frills spot. 

Here's how my night progressed...

1. Ordered a PBR ($4) and bellied up to the bar 
2. The bartender offered me some of his gummy bears and I kindly accepted. Pure gold. 
3. Took a shot of Irish whiskey
4. Listened to two patrons play guitar in the back of the bar
5. Exited the bar

My advice, is to experience this place ASAP. There are few gems left in this city and the Black Horse embodies what I love about the "old" San Francisco. It's also a great place to watch a soccer game on Saturday morning.
author: Benjamin F.

description: I've lived here 12 years and this is my Cheers. Say hi to James (owner) and give him crap about the Indians Cavaliers and Browns haha.  Bear Honey may be guarding the door.
author: Geno B.

description: What a crap hole. The owner gets beer at Costco by the case and chills it in an old bath tub behind the bar. Everyone in there thinks their  doesn't stink because they're shoulder to shoulder getting a niche and "authentic" bar experience by going to this place. Complete joke. Also, the guy who runs the place sucks at playing guitar and nobody has the marbles to tell him. Lame
author: Richard J.

description: I love this bar. - intimate, fun, cool patrons, occasional games, the owner is cool as fkkk, bartenders are super chill... my go-to when I stay in the area whilst in San Francisco...
author: Lilia R.

description:
Suuuuuuuuper freaking sweet y'all!!

I walked into this place sooo confused and lost cause it was NOT what I expected. But the people here from the staff to the attendees will turn your frown upside down in a heartbeat. They are super cool, have some funny but honorable rules hung on the wall I suggest you check out before getting comfortable lol. 

Only missing a star cause I had trecked so far to this place thinking they had hard liquor but it was only beer, but honestly that's just the drinker in me being picky. These people are so sweet and definitely worth the visit. I'm taking a friend there this weekend(and I'm from Sacramento lol).
author: Anissa W.

description: Been going for years. Great local experience and very welcoming! Nice, cozy bar ambiance and great spot for beer and a chat. Always making new friends there with the patrons.
author: Jonathan M.

description: This is hands down my favorite bar in San Francisco. My friend recommend it to me and told me I have to go no matter what. I was not disappointed this bar is a hidden gem as soon as I walked in I was greeted by the bartender JC and all the patrons, sat down and had a few cold ones. If you are looking for a fun and awesome time definitely come in and experience it for yourself! Also shoutout to JC the man behind the bar keeping the beer and tunes coming! Best bartender in SF!
author: Willie U.

description: Best pub in San Francisco.  Friendly locals and a genuinely nice place to hang out and have a laugh for a couple of hours.  No pretentions...just a fun place to be.
author: Tim D.

description: How many places would have a bar that only seats 9 people and serves great Brit ales and Belgian beers out of a bathtub full of ice? this has to be the most unusual bar I've ever been in, and I've been in quite a few. The bartenders and the other patrons are super friendly too.
author: Nina L.

description: Itsy Bitsy, Inny tiny, famous for being small. Yawn. Can you say  Clicky? Parking is a pain, arrive by bus...too crowded? Keep cruising down Union street for a plethora of bigger better bars.
author: Laurel G.

description: Randomly walked into this pub over the weekend. Coined as the smallest bar in San Francisco this pub literally has seating for less than 10 people! Beers served out of a bathtub on ice behind the corner. Random memorabilia pinned up all over the walls. Every neighborhood needs a small hang out spot like this where everyone is friendly, the bartender knows your name and suds are continuously flowing.
author: Ralph A.

description: Totally not what I expected. It must be where they coined the phrase "hole in the wall." Super nice bartender and regulars, but.... I came for good beer, and I was disappointed.
author: Sarah D.

description: Extremely small place. Only about 6 people fit inside. We were unable to even walk in as it was a hole in the wall
author: Carlos C.

description:
File this under Another Thank You To Yelp for finding me a cool place.

I was out with my dog in SF and wanted to find a dog-friendly place to have a beer and watch the Chargers vs. Raiders game.  And while the Chargers didn't deliver, as they were wont to do this season, the Black Horse did.

Realize that the place is tiny.  The Village Pub in Carlsbad can accommodate 18 people comfortably, and maybe 30 in a United Airlines level of comfort.  Black Horse accommodates half that.  But it's the friendly half.

Bartender (owner?) James had 8 types of bottled beer available, all chilling in an old-house porcelain bathtub.  I went for a Kloster Andechs, a German abbey lager I'd never hear of before, and kept coming back for more.  The other 8 seats were periodically filled with locals and tourists, and my adorable Pit/Lab pup, The Wee Baby Ava, pulled up a spot in the doorway and greeted everyone who came in.

But we're not just talking dog-friendly here.  When one customer got a serious swerve going on, James not only summoned a Uber, but did it using his own account. That's incredibly kind.

When in SF, I'll be back!
author: Erik S.

description:
First time I have come here! Got very impressed, specially with the decoration on the walls.
Nice place, sort of a small place to hang out with your friends and have a good time. Nice appetizers and really good service. Cool atmosphere.
author: Janes R.

description: A unique gem that's great if your up for something uniquely great and different.  A very friendly Englishman and fellow staff serve you ice cold beer and cider from a bathtub.  There is room for about 8-12 people.  Make friends, actually chat with people, imbibe and be jolly!
author: Nathan M.

description: This is a tiny bar.   The owner, James, was extremely friendly. The atmosphere is outstanding.  The bar only fits about 15 people, but you get to chat with strangers who are super friendly and helpful when looking for good restaurants and bars in the area.  This is a must hit place in San Fran if you are staying in the area.
author: Paul M.

description:
This is what it is: a neighborhood bar that is to the point. Very few drinks available but not over priced. 

The drinks are all on ice and kept cold in a bathtub. The bathroom is small. The whole place is small. You really just cannot fit a lot of people here. 

The bartenders and owners are all awesome though. The owner will make men get up so women can sit down, which is so gentlemanly. They were all amazing to talk to. 

Everyone acts like family and friends here. I really liked it and would definitely go back if I'm ever in town. Just don't expect some amazing mixology cocktails happening here.
author: Janice L.

description: A little bar with a lot of character. Visiting The Black London definitely bettered our experience in San Francisco. We enjoyed the company and got some great restaurant recommendations! Thank you and hopefully we'll be visiting again.
author: Mindy L.

description: We were there a few days before St. Patrick's Day 2017 and the place was packed with lads from Roscommon, Ireland. Since I was one of only two gals in the place, I was quite happy! Plenty of Irish song and a bottle of Jameson passed round. Was a splendid night!
author: Michele M.

description:
Love this place.

Tiny, adorable, cash only (I think?), and they take barters.  Ie. if you have foreign money, a cool pin, or an old ring who knows... you might get a beer for it and they'll put it up amongst their other eclectic decor.  This place also has a lot of history and not many beers on tap regardless, the visit is for the ambiance, local flavor, and stimulating conversation with the bar keep.

All in all, I plan to visit again.  Great place to take visitors-but not too many, it is pretty small inside.
author: Sara N.

description: Really small bar with bartenders that have really large personalities. Lots of regulars so you might feel left out at first but James and Cassandra will make you feel right at home before you know it. Come here to get away from the regular bar scene.
author: Gonzalo S.

description: Lord what a wonderfully eclectic hole in the wall. It's like snuggling with strangers in a drunk shoe box but you'll love every second of it. Reasonable prices. Fantastic company from the employees to the customers. I had a wonderful time here on my visit to San Francisco and would gladly return on every trip.
author: Hollie M.

description: So tiny but that's what makes this place awesome (unless you get stuck in here with 5-6 Marina douchebags )
author: Tauasa T.

description: Great place to go to for good company and beer! Plus, who doesn't want to say they have been to the smallest bar in San Francisco?!
author: Sara W.

description: Found this place right here on yelp. What a cool place. Very small but that is what I liked about it. My wife and I were in there about 10 minutes and a local regular came in and bought the place a round. Thanks Mike. We played out favorite dice game (10,000) with one of the bartenders. Thanks for kicking our ass Kim. Overall great little place to hang out. This will be a regular place for us to visit when we go to the city.
author: Robert H.

description: I hadn't been here for awhile - such a charming little place with purplish soft lighting.  Their selection of beers changes according to what is in stock and in season.  Loved the bartenders, especially Kimberly!  I will be back!
author: Maile N.

description:
Drunk bartender berated a group inappropriately. Not worth it.
He claimed that the party had left a used tissue on the ground. Not sure what actually happened but his behavior was beyond a normal response. Won't go back.
author: Eli H.

description:
This is the best bar in San Francisco. Hell it might be my favorite bar in the country. The Black Horse London Pub (or B-Ho as my friends and I call it) located in the Marina district. I first came here with my buddies (and regulars at the bar) Stefan and Stephen. I was visiting the Bay Area for WWDC and Stefan told me I had to come to this place before I left. Best advice ever. Now that I live in the city I stop there whenever I get the chance.

FREQUENCY: I've been to the Black Horse more times than i can count. A lot of times I'm there once a week but on a good week it's twice.

FOOD: They don't serve any. If you're hungry then stop somewhere else beforehand but make sure to come back for some drinks, you won't regret it.

DRINK: The Black Horse only serves beer so if you aren't a beer fan this place might not be your favorite. But the atmosphere is amazing so read on before you decide not to go just because there's only beer. You can order a PBR for $4 (and shotgun with the bartender if you so dare) and most other beers are around ~$6. The beers are served out of a tub and the selection changes pretty regularly. The selection always seems to have a good variety of beer styles.

ATMOSPHERE: This is the smallest bar in SF. Honestly would believe that it's the smallest bar in the country. You are either sitting at the bar of squeezed one to two rows of people behind the bar stools. This place does not fit a lot of people. They will make you sit up for women (as they should) to sit. There's one TV but what I love about this place is the social aspect. James the owner is always there drinking with the regulars. Either he or a patron may pull out a guitar and sing later on into the night. I always meet and talk to new people here. If you aren't outgoing you might not enjoy the Black Horse because you don't really get personal space in there. There is a ton of cool memorabilia on the wall that lends to the atmosphere. Watch out, this place is so small you could walk or drive right by it without realizing. The bar does close at midnight though so make sure to watch the clock and get your drinks in. Don't worry though, there are bars around the corner to move on to.

STAFF: The staff is amazing. They are a lot of fun to drink with and won't hesitate to call you on your shit. Like I said, I've shotgunned with them, chugged with them, sang with them, and always have a great time with them. You're missing out by not meeting these people.

PAYMENT: The Black Horse is cash only but there is an ATM at the corner store right next to the bar.

I started with it and I'll end with it. This is the best bar in SF. The atmosphere it great, the staff is great, and the patrons are great. I've never had a bad time here and I doubt I ever will. I tell everyone they should stop by this bar at least once and give it a try. I know I'll be there again relatively soon. Most likely tonight.
author: Christopher D.

description:
My  favor  Bar in SF.

love  visiting there with my  group. 

drinks are cheap ,  music is great,   people and service is  perfect  .  i so love that place.

the place is unique   no doubt.   you must  visit to see.
author: Jaime J.

description:
Small, cozy, and unique. Make sure you stop by for comedy night.

It's cash only and all the beer is on ice in a old bath tub. This is truly a one-of-a-kind spot.
author: Nathan C.

description:
This bar. My friends and i walked a mile uphill to get to this bar. Sign outside says deli, I was a bit worried; had I looked up a sandwich shop?
I look inside and it looks like a hallway in a house, but actually. A hallway with a bar in the middle of it. It fit about 12 people. Ladies always get a seat first. Hurray. It was still bright outside, a unique change from the usually dark can hardly see what I'm drinking bars.
Everyone seemed to know each other. Everyone was super friendly. 
James was a lit major. If you can guess the author or book the quote on the wall comes from, you get a free beer.
There's about 8 different beers, 1 beer on top, and beers from a bathtub.
Oh, and the bathroom is marked "WC" for water closet. 
It was kind of awesome. Anyone can own a bar, anywhere, if you have the right attitude.
Def one of a kind.
author: Trang B.

description:
I know I'm an idiot; I have to be, don't I?  A tiny closet-sized space that only seats a half dozen people?  One beer on tap, and the rest in a damned bathtub behind the bar?

YES!!!  I'm not addicted to eclectic or off-the-wall establishments, but this place is exactly what I look for in a neighborhood watering hole.

Let me explain: The "one beer" on tap is invariably a fine craft ale that has been cask-conditioned and hard to find.  The beers in the tub are well-iced and of a great and insane variety.  The interior is as madcap a collection of conversation pieces as one could hope for, and last (but by no means least) James is just plain cool as shit.  The few other patrons that can crowd in are almost forced into conversation with one another, and James drives the whole experience like a master social conductor waving a baton made of beer.

Yes I know that metaphor made no sense.  

Just go here before you die or you LOSE.
author: Tim S.

description: Stumbled on his place and loved it. If you want to feel like a local while visiting this is a good stop through for a beer.
author: Elizabeth R.

description: Had some beer with a packed bar full of friendly regulars.  Helped said group of friendly regulars take out the recycling.  Watch a british man totally fail at shotgunning a PBR.  Found a well stocked library in the bathroom.  Victory.
author: P J.

description:
This is probably my favorite bar in SF. My friends and I nearly always leave with a story or two. 

The beer in the tub changes most days so prepare to be flexible. Ladies, if you ask nicely you might get a mug of wine if you don't fancy the brews.
author: Owen Conor H.

description:
We'd read reviews that this place was small, but when we approached the door I was so taken aback that I hesitated until the bartender beckoned, cheerfully shouting "C'mon in, there's plenty of room!" We walked in, one of the gentleman gave up a barstool for me and we ordered a bottled beer from the bathtub behind the bar.

So glad we listened. James and Cassandra, the bartenders, were amazing. They navigated the minuscule behind-the-bar space like a well-practiced waltz, chatting and playing a dice game called "One, Four, Twenty-Four" with locals and visitors alike. They were running a show, but not in a way that was at all unauthentic - you can tell they genuinely liked being there and enjoyed hosting people in their strange little bar. Without them, I really doubt this kind of space would work. 

If you're in Marina, stop by. It's awesome.
author: Scarlett C.

description:
James (the owner) is the man.  Love this joint.  All the alcohol (and by alcohol, I mean just bottled beer) is kept in a big bathtub behind the bar full of ice.

It's also probably the smallest bar in SF....I think it has only like 6 seats at the counter.

But a great place to spend time and shoot the sh$t with James.  If you ask nicely, he may pull out his guitar and sing you a little ditty.
author: Edward M.

description: Awesome tiny spot with maybe 10 seats. Always a kick back easy mellow feel. Think old school San Francisco no frills beer drinking. Fellow Patons become friends fast. Just reliably lovely. Awesome bartender is such a nice change.
author: Amy L.

description: Effing amazing. But it's about the size of a shoebox so don't plan on bringing your bridal shower down here. The space is dominated by a bathtub which houses the evenings beer offerings and empties, and which the bartendress regularly has to scale to maneuver her way around the place. But it's effing fantastic. Love love love this place. Best pub in SF.
author: Gary B.

description: I always stop in for a beer when I visit San Fran. It's tiny, tiny. Dollar bills on the wall along with other memorabilia give it a nice charm. The girl that tends the bar is friendly, as well. Will keep coming back.
author: James E.

description: By far my new favorite bar. The smallest bar in San Francisco has stolen my heart. It's a bar that makes you feel like you're just one of the gang. Relaxed atmosphere, but not a full bar. only serves beer.
author: Alyssa E.

description: So we ran into this bar wanting to take a quick shot before our bus arrived in 6 minutes. So glad we did.  First, they don't sell liquor but everyone was super welcoming and it appeared to be stand up comedy night. The lady we heard was pretty hilarious and we were able to chug an ice cold beer just in time for the bus to arrive. If we didn't have to get back to Berkeley, we would have stayed longer. So glad we happened upon this bar on our week in San Francisco. This was on a Wednesday night, btw. Not sure if they have comedy every night.
author: Sheela Y.

description: Excellent little pub with great staff! Best bar in San Fran!! It has to be everyones local
author: Andrew S.

description:
First, I've seen bigger walk in closets. This place is tiny. Second, they only serve bottles of beer. Third, they close at midnight. Forth, they have a dart board you can't use.

In spite of all this, if you're brave enough to walk in when it's empty, packed, or something in between, you get a chance to talk with some of the fantastic and friendly drunken degenerates that inhabit the black horse. Come and have a drink, play some 1-4-24, and get to know the regulars. If you're brave enough to venture in, you're likely to come back. If for no other reason than to try and win your 1-4-24 money back.

See you there!
author: Preston B.

description:
If you come here and don't have a nice time, you're doing something wrong. It's about half the size of our old apartment but filled with ten times more charm, cheeriness, and good manners than our place ever had.

Before my dear friend left San Francisco, I told her she had to come with me to the smallest pub in town. She did and now, even though I didn't find her a husband, she can die with no regrets. 

Don't leave this world, or San Francisco, without regrets. Come to the Black Horse, make some new friends, and just imagine how cool the world would be if everyone was this polite.
author: Loli L.

description:
The fire code for the Black Horse London pub tops off at 22 people. Quite frankly, I think this is way high. I cannot see how to 22 people could squeeze their way into this establishment, let alone exit it safely in an emergency.

There are 12 bar stools against the bar. There is no refrigerator, just a claw footed bathtub full of ice and bottles of beer. I believe there's also one keg. I sure hope the bartender's favorite game is the floor is lava, because she was literally crawling across the bathtub to serve people.

Perhaps it's a coincidence, but I'm guessing it has a lot to do with the atmosphere, the people in this bar are the friendliest around. We met a lot of amazing, outgoing, kind people in San Francisco. But nowhere else was it so easy, and so necessary, to start a conversation with a complete stranger. I got the sense that this bar has an awful lot of regulars. If I lived in San Francisco, I would be one, too.
author: Kate D. B.

description: Great hole in the wall full of charismatic chatty locals. It's the smallest bar in SF (a walled off alley way). Definitely worth stopping in for a few beers!
author: Whitney W.

description:
The list of 10 Commandments nailed to the wall dictate something along the lines of "Thou shalt give up your seat to a woman." as the first commandment. HELL-TO-THE-YESSSSS! 

At last, a pub/bar that commands chivalry. Long dead in our society, it's nice to experience a bit of it in this lifetime. The bar owner is extremely friendly, and the people who come here are as well. I had been wondering why this bar was so small (it's about the size of a small hallway), so the owner enlightened me.

This had been an alleyway between two buildings, and the previous owner had been genius enough to turn this into a place of business. Boom, bang, a few decades later, and you have The Black Horse.

Beer preserved in a claw-foot tub, friendly pub-goers, an owner who's so friendly, if he had one more droplet of friendliness in him, he'd implode, and an intimate ambiance that allows for actual conversation = my new favorite bar in all of SF.

I like intimate bars. I like intimate bars that once upon a time, used to be an alleyway, even more.
author: Ellie W.

description: An awesome must visit pub in SF!! Small but  such a hidden gem!! Only one bar counter with about 9 seats around and bar rules are if a lady walks in a gentlemen MuST give up his seat!! So sweet!! And don't get me started on the owner James!! He is such a great Host!! Gets to know everyone in his bar and gives great food advice!! So funny!!
author: Judy K.

description: A great place to stop by and meet some folks. One of the friendliest bars in SF. Both James and Cassandra are wonderful folks.
author: Da Wei S.

description:
What a great place for a random night.

I stumbled upon this place on Yelp one night when I was out alone on a work trip to SF. I stopped in for a drink and stayed for a few hours. I love the charm of this place and the welcoming nature. The bar kind of naturally selects for people willing to have a conversation with the person next to them. Also, there's a great burger place nearby that you can go and bring food back from (grab a burger for the bartender too).
author: Bryan R.

description:
The smallest bar in the world. Period. I mean that in a good way by the way. The staff is what makes this place great. They introduce themselves and get to know you by name. 

When I was visiting San Fran, I wanted to get a couple of drinks before I went back home. Looked this place up and saw that they had some good reviews but didn't look at the pictures on how small it was hahaha. Walked in and people were playing a card game and invited us in to play. Awesome. 

They only have bottle beer, but a good variety. No food. Cash only. 

Wish they had some beers on tap and would accept credit cards.
author: Hugo M.

description:
Great experience after having my farewell dinner. We actually just wanted to grab one beer but a couple hours/beers later we were still in there. 
Good variety of beers. I am from Germany so I know what I am talking about! :p
Friendly barkeeper with lots of knowledge about beer but please give her some sleep. This 5-hour energy stuff is not the way to go.....
Cool drinking games and nice ambiance thanks to the small size of the place...

Bottom line: Ill def. come back as soon as I am back in town
author: Daniel J.

description: Was in town and staying down the street. Decided to have a drink at the first bar we found and are so glad we found this place. Discovered a coffee stout that was fantastic AND it was movie night! Score! Mars Attacks came with a drinking game and six new friends! Perfect Tuesday evening!
author: Kristin P.

description:
Why 5 stars?  Because I felt like I was amongst nothing but bff's.

   ---   ---   ---

Yelp, you sonofabee.  After walking around San Francisco by myself for a couple of days, I found my way to BHLP.  Upon entering the threshold of the door way, I completely forgot that I was alone in the city and felt like a super regular at the local pub.  I was greeted and treated so warmly while I was there, I am still kind of amazed by it.  As I walked in, everything kind of stopped and everyone seemed to turn their attention to chatting with me.  That makes me sound like a narcissistic blow hard, but who doesn't like that kind of treatment when you're riding solo?

It is as small as others have pointed out.  Including the bathrooms, I don't know if they could fit 25 people in there, personal space be damned.  I feel like that kind intimacy adds to the charm.

I asked about the 1-4-24 game that I read about, and was once again, they seemed to be at my service and dropped everything to bust the game out for me.  It's a really fun and addicting game that's perfect for the bar.  I recommend you all check out Black Horse for the rules and explanations.  I'm sure you can google it, but why not add some adventure into your life and check out the ole' pub and learn about the way people used to before the internet?

I had some good beer while I was there as well.  I wish I could remember what they were, but nay.  The selection was definitely quality over quantity.  I'll be back during my next visit to SF.
author: Brett N.

description: If I had only had more than 30 minutes in this perfect bar. That would be my one wish before dying. I love this pub and will definitely return - knowing how to play 1-4-24 next time. But don't go when you visit... it's a perfect local gem. Never change, Black Horse.
author: Greg K.

description: This is an awesome pub in San francisco. A friend of mine and I wanted to checkout Marina bars, and kind of stumbled into this place (Thanks Yelp :). This place is so intimate and super friendly. Had super conversations with the Bartender who also was supposedly a great baker and treated her with superb treats. Beer selection was good, but the coziness and friendly atmosphere beats everything else :) This place is a must visit if you're visiting the city.
author: Shriram R.

description:
What an absolute beauty! 

This is one of the smallest bars I've ever been in - but boy is it worth squishing up.

Beers are cheap and served from a bath tub filled with ice! You could be excused for thinking you're at a friends housewarming - if they moved into a 40sqm apartment.

The size of the bar gives it a great ambience - it almost feels like everyone knows each other.

Having arrived without local currency, we were given free beers by the owner, after donating some foreign currency to the wall (there is a space on the wall covered in foreign currency - I donated South African Rands and Mozambiquean mets). 

Our second round of beers were paid for by one of the friendly patrons who couldn't cope with the idea of us leaving as a result of our non cash carrying habits.

The only devastation was the bar closing at 12 on a weeknight 

Great spot - worth checking out, especially if you live in the area.
author: Peet K.

description:
This bar is super small. No joke, the max capacity is no more than 10 people. That's cool but, beyond that, there's not much to love.

Most importantly, it's not a "dive" because it's not exactly cheap. The bottled beers (served from a tub) are $5 or $6 and there are no brews on tap. This upsets me.

Also, the service is a little strange. The bartender said "I don't know you" when we walked in. Typically I like this sort of sass but it wasn't delivered properly. She then told us about her parent's marital problems. Girl, I don't need to hear this, I'm just trying to get my drink on!

Anyway, the size is fun but everything else is below average.
author: Nick K.

description:
This is one of those places that's so unique and off the radar that you really feel like you've discovered something special by stumbling in here.

The bar is incredibly small, the smallest in San Francisco I've been told. The $5 beers they serve, out of a bath tub behind the counter mind you, have varied every time I've been here. The oddest thing about this place is that there's a dartboard on one of the walls, which I'm sure has never been used due to the risk of impaling a patron given you'd have to throw right above people's heads.

The thing that makes this really special is that because of intimate size, you inevitably end up becoming friends with the people sitting next to you and the bartender by the end of the night. They also have a no cell phone rule that's really refreshing given how much of a distraction that can be on the here and now.

If you're in the neighborhood you should also head down to Black Magic Voodoo Lounge and stretch out a bit.
author: Madhu P.

description: What a great experience...not sure words can describe. It reminds me of times in my past where you don't need to talk on your phone or be distracted by the daily chaos of life. Enjoy a conversation or a quiet moment while having a beer served out of a bath tub  (nothing else is served) James was great.....enough said...
author: Tim H.

description: Best pub in town.  Owner is charming and invites customers to play games with dice.  Rules are women sit, while men stand.  It's the tiniest bar in SF, but the best imho.
author: Molly C.

description: Being a freak about all things London, I had to stop in this adorable pub on the way home one night. It's very small but that adds to the ambiance. The pubs in London are fairly small and are there for beer and beer only!  If they happen to have food, it's usually marginal. This was a great place to grab a brew and enjoy an hour after work!
author: Sandra P.

description: Great beer selection, great employees. Love coming here with my sister when I go up and visit the bay
author: Sam R.

description: We heard this bar was pet friendly, so of course we had to give it a try! It is very tiny. Maybe there are 8 barstools in the whole place and it's a cash only bar. But it has a lot of character and they allowed us to bring our dog in so we couldn't have asked for more. They had a nice variety of beers. Not your standard Heineken or Budweiser which is a nice change. They're only five bucks too. There are a couple of TVs and it was a neat diversified crown of neighborhood locals. If we are in the neighborhood or at the nearby dog park and craving a beer, we will definitely choose the black horse!
author: Kelsey K.

description: Didn't check the pictures of the place before coming so we were kind of surprised to find out that the bar is the size of a college dorm room. Nonetheless, this place is a great spot to grab an afternoon beer and watch the Giants play. The bartender was really nice and we chatted about all the different people who stroll on through the bar. They have quite a collection of international dollar bills so be sure to bring something cool to add to the wall!
author: Derek L.

description: Simply the best bar in the entire city.  Some of the most memorable nights of my life have been here...from walking into a U2/Oasis singalong at 2am on NYE, or when the whole bar sat riveted watching "Piranha" together.  But the best part of the bar is simple: the diverse crowd and James/Cassandra, the oddest best friends you'll ever meet.  Not a trendy scene, not an amazing selection of alcohol, just an endearingly quirky true "neighbors" bar with an interesting mix of very squished people.  A true SF treasure.
author: James S.

description: This is a tiny bar with great service and every time I've gone in I have had great conversations and it's super friendly.  I bring all my friends there!
author: W. Z.

description: This is not only the smallest bar in SF but the friendliest! James and Kim were so nice! We were there celebrating our birthdays and they made us feel so welcome. The locals were very friendly, too.  We ended up buying the whole bar a round (it is the smallest bar after all)!! We will definitely go back!
author: Janell G.

description:
My wife and I visited the Black Horse on our honeymoon in 2010....and its taken me this long to write a review...we visited other restaurants and bars through out San Fransisco but we ended up at the "Deli"every night.

It's everything everyone says, smaller than small..but you walk in and James the barkeep  introduces you to everyone, and its like going to a party with your best friends.
Beer is served out of a bathtub, and you can gamble on a dice game at the bar.....If  your looking for a nice piano bar with elegant decor..then keep looking...if you like some good beer guzzeling with great fun people..look no further.

I've been to countless pubs and bars all over the world....and so far... this place is my No # 1. favorite....
author: R. S.

description: James and Cassandra are both uniquely amazing in their own right! I loved the welcoming vibe in this tiny, overcrowded bar that serves a delicious rotating selection of bottled beers beautifully chilled in a bathtub behind the bar. The first night I visited I was reluctant to go in being so packed and standing room only but the regulars truly respect the rules--men are expected give or at least offer their chair to a lady. Chivalry is nice...especially when "dems da rules" :) and you've been walking all day! I wish they were in the LBC, because I love it hear that much! Come on into the BLACK HORSE LONDON PUB, you will have a great time... Oh and bring that stash of Cash!!! $
author: Jessica C.

description:
My Local Pub! it's small and I like it! 
Great service, Great people!
author: Phil L.

description: James is friendly and hospitable.  Cassandra is a consummate professional and an A+ hoopsta.  The beer is quality.  And the customers are quirky and fun.  Shame on me for not stopping in more often.  New-leaf time.
author: Scott W.

description: My friend and I were walking around the Marina looking for a good spot and decided to check this place out.  It was smaller than I thought it would be, but that's actually one of the best parts!  Everyone is friendly, and I've met a lot of great people here. They are cash and beer only, but that works for me!  I live near the ballpark so it's a little bit of a trek, but it's worth it!  Awesome place.
author: Ian P.

description: Went here last night and had a margarita that was on par, wish I had another and glass could have used on salt. Place is small and people are great. James made sure he makes you feel at home. My only complaint is that its small.
author: Oliver G.

description:
I'm tempted to give is a low rating to keep the crowds away - because the place can't hold them.  The only reason I don't give the Black Horse 5 stars is because it is not for everyone - as evidenced by the occasional bad rating (though I can't figure out how someone who has never been inside has the nerve to rate a place).  Small, cozy, tiny, or any other similar adjective will barely fit in the door.  When we lived in the area, this was a regular stop for us.  Now that we live out in "San Ramote", we only get here about once a month.  It is well worth the stop when we are in the City.

James (the owner) is great and the place is friendly.  The beer selection is as small as the pub, but high quality.  There is usually a Chimay or two on the list, another beer from Germany, Austria, or other beer making country.  Sometimes he has another selection such as a hard cider on the list.  There is also a cask ale on tap, something you should at least try (not carbonated, solid taste).  And he has the proper glassware for each type of beer.  Chimay should not be consumed out of your standard wedge shaped pint glass that most places use.

The cheese plates are top notch.  Yes, they are served on paper plates - but you don't eat the plate.  For your money you will get two high quality cheeses (love the English Cheddar), a tasty meat (usually salami), some great bread, a healthy serving of chutney, some onions, and a sliced apple.  Order the large plate and share, you may meet a new acquaintance.

If you want wine, go to Amalie or The Wine Bar on Polk.  If you want hard liquor, go back up Union street to any number of places.  If you are looking for a place to be seen by the in crowd, go to Vessal. But if you want a friendly place where you can hang and have a conversation while sipping some quality beer, this is your place.  Stop here on the way to the other places, you may never make it to where you were originally going.

So Dee C., next time you walk by why don't you pop in.  You might actually meet some real people and have fun talking to them.  And given that you are female, you will always get a seat.  But don't use your cell phone or you will be asked to leave.

XMAS 07 UPDATE:
Went there twice over the holidays.  Good time had by all.  On Christmas Day James served his special Glog - very yummy.  We met 3 Kiwi's, a Texan cowboy, and several other new friends.  Gave James a framed print of his place (uploaded here).  It's now hanging on the wall behind the bar.
author: Jeff H.

description:
The Chinese calendar has designated 2010 as the Year of the Tiny. Hence therefore twice removed, The Black Horse has been deemed bar of the year.

If my room at the Harbor Court is a womb, then the Horse is the birth canal. Seven seats at a bar that's a Fat Albert away from the frame-adorned walls. Bottled beer ($5-8, cash only) served from an ice-filled bathtub in which you'd expect to wake up, sans kidney. Tips in a hanging pitcher and a corkboard loaded with tacked-on foreign currency, just because.

The one TV on high is useless, as your face will be in the back of the head of the guy who's standing in front of you, just as the party-back of your mullet is filling the nostrils of the man standing behind you. Rest assured, assuming you're male, you will be standing. The first of ten Rules of the Bar mandate sacrificing your stool to any lady in an act of shotgun chivalry. The rules are enforced, much to the chagrin of two goobers who didn't want to move. Sorry Charlie!

It's here I learned of a magnificent dice game called 1-4-24. And because you learn the rules when you manwich your way to your first beer at the Horse, I'll spare you the details.

Go, drink, be born again.
author: Damien S.

description:
I've been to some small towns in my time. Places where your next door neighbor and the guy on the other side of town are the same person. Some would call it cozy or quaint, others claustrophobic.

The Black Horse is unapologetically small. Its smallness is its greatest feature. Not that it doesn't have anything else going for it. The décor--mostly football memorabilia (soccer to us yanks)--is tacked up with no real organization or explanation. There's also a large flat screen TV that inexplicably played a poker tournament on mute the night I visited. Who cares? There's also a corkboard with small denomination bills from all over the world pinned to it.

Like a small town, you get to know your neighbor. It's kind of unavoidable when you're so packed in that you're rubbing your goods and services against them all night long, and vice-versa. By the end of the night, you'll know what kind of cell phone everyone has in their pocket.

Just like in those great small towns that cover the country, there are unwritten rules to obey at the Black Horse. The greatest of these, is that women have preference on the bar stools. When a lady comes in, she gets the stool. No questions asked.

Drinks were nothing fancy. It's bottled beer + and cash only, at that. But it's all about community. And whether you're pressing the flesh with the guy next to you, or playing a spirited game of 1-4-24, it's definitely about the crowd (and being crowded) at The Black Horse.
author: Jeffrey S.

description: If there's ever been a place to get to know a stranger, it's the black horse. Smallest bar west of the Mississippi, the owner proclaims, with about nine barstools, you're going to be cozy. It's a place to meet and make friends, the regulars are all warm and welcoming, they'll rope you into having a beer (....or 4) more than you signed up for but you'll go home a happier person for all the good times and quality conversations you have shared. Fantastic staff, unique beer selection, absolutely fabulous. All my love to the Horse!
author: Hunter S.

description:
Double midnight! 

Besides the extra-small interior that everyone has already mentioned, the one thing that sticks out in my mind about Black Horse is the crazy dice game that's played on the tiny counter space within. Don't ask me how it's played, 'cause I'm slow to catch on and even slower to remember, but it has something to do with 1's and 4's and the number 22. And I'm not a bettin' woman, so you're just going to have to go there and see for yourself!
author: Abby S.

description: I stopped into The Black Horse not knowing that it's the size of a shoebox (my brother and I were on our way to a fancy steak dinner). No matter, though; the crowd was super-friendly and respectful -- a necessary feature when every two minutes someone has to slide out of the way to make room for someone else. Making conversation with other folks seems almost expected; the bartenders and other patrons chatted both me and my brother up within a few minutes of entering. A fun experience overall.
author: Bill H.

description:
The Black Horse would be my favorite bar ever if only they'd throw some sparkling splits in their bathtub of beer. Don't get me wrong I enjoy delicious beer, but I can literally drink about two in one sitting before I become full and truthfully I want to stay here longer than that. Perhaps someone from the Black Horse is reading this and is willing to put Sophia in their menu rotation? It's the can of sparkling wine that comes with its own sipping straw like a juice box and I think it would fit right into your eclectic selection and the ladies that you are so kind to already would love it.

Ah hell, who am I kidding really? The Black Horse is pretty much my favorite bar even with just the beer because it's just that awesome. It can hold maybe 16 people at once and there are people spilling out onto the sidewalks. It's crowded, but no one is pushy. It's the opposite in fact; everyone is friendly and trying to figure out how they can help you get in to get a beer. Plus they are very kind to ladies with rules about letting ladies have the seats at the bar and that guys have to stand. I like this show of chivalry.

And once you're sitting down (or standing up if you're a boy) you can engage in a game of 1, 4, 24 for $1. It involves dice and rolling certain numbers, but that's all I'll say - you have to learn for yourself if you ever make it there.

I think what I'm trying to say here is Black Horse, I heart you.
author: Tiffany N.

description: a nice place, all friendly ppl! last year before i drive to LV for ces, I was so happy to meet some guys here!
author: Huang C.

description:
Neat little bar with a friendly atmosphere.  Within minutes you will know everyone and talk to each other like you were neighbors or friends.  Conversation was constant and topics ever changing.  It was interesting.  Beer was a little more than other places and I figure since it is such a small bar and can only serve a certain amount of people, one way to at least make a profit is to charge a little more. 

 It would've been four stars but It appears that they do allow smoking inside here which made me take away a star.  If this place was bigger I seriously wouldn't have minded at all.  but when someone is next to you smoking in such a TINY area there is no escaping it.  Seriously, if I started farting and it stunk up the room would everyone be fine with it? (Maybe some guys would be amused)  Or would at least the ladies be offended if I sat next to them and pass a little gas.  Well that is how smoking next to me is.  Just my opinion.
author: Aaron A.

description:
If there was one place in San Fran that I wish I could shrink down, put in my pocket and take to Cleveland, it would be Black Horse.

Strangely enough, I wouldn't actually have to make it much smaller than it already is to be able to carry it with me. And trust me, I'm a pretty small lady. This bar is literally the size of a long closet and is actually THE tiniest pub in California... possibly even the entire United States. 

This little spot consists of a small bar with maybe 10 stools and enough space for one person to fit behind you. Not an over exaggeration. Behind the bar there really isn't much more room to work with, which might be why the beers are stored in an old bathtub filled with ice. I don't even think you could fit commercial sized coolers in here. 

Black Horse is a cash only bar with about 8 tasty beers to choose from. That's it. There are a couple of rules that you have to follow here as well. For one, no cell phone use in the bar. I find this to be a relief in such a small space. Also, it's just kind of rude, but hey... whatev. I like it. Second, ladies always get the bar stools. What an amazingly refreshing idea! A bar that instills manners and chivalry? WOW. I'm thoroughly impressed!

The sense of community and family in this little bar is intense. I mean, talk about regulars. These people call talk about this joint like it's theirs... like they own the place. I love that. Besides, if you're going to stand that close to one another and drink, it's probably hard not to be like family. Plus you get built-in entertainment with a house dice game called 24. Pretty much everyone pitches in a dollar to the pot to play and it actually gets pretty intense (in a nice way). I'm definitely bringing this game back to Cleveland. 

Oh, and I saved the best part for last. I was sitting at this tiny bar, enjoying the close-knit feeling, sipping on a delish cider and wondering why I felt so at home. Welp, turns out the owner is actually from Cleveland! Ahhhhhh, a little taste of CLE all the way out in Cali. Priceless.
author: Cara L.

description: Haha, I seem to run back and forth from Black Magic Voodoo Lounge to this place!
author: Steve F.

description:
This is by far the smallest bar I've ever been to. Its not the size of the ship it's the motion of the ocean and in terms of coolness the Black Horse popped several Viagras. 

The max capacity is about 20 people, and they only serve beer and wine that is kept cold via bathtub behind the bar. It really kind of resembles a college dorm room converted into a saloon. 

The greatest part about hanging here is the fact that you get to know everyone in the place. You can't help, but strike up a conversation when sitting inches from the next barfly. 

The bartender (I'm assuming owner) is super chill and will play dice with the patrons, but watch out he's got a hot hand. 

Certainly not the type of place to hit up if you want to rage against the machine, but if a chill couple of beers is your tone for the night this place is right up your alley.
author: Danny W.

description: You have to have a bar. And you have to have only one. If I would live in SF there is a good chance it would be the Black Horse. Only a few people fit in but it worth to squeeze in.  European beers served from a bathtub by the friendly saff. Some patroons were challenging each other with bar tricks. I will be visit again for sure.
author: György M.

description:
This is bar is like drinking in your best friends' basement when his parents are out of town for the weekend and his alcoholic father forget to lock up his good beer. What? Don't look at me like that. I know I can't be the only one who had this experience growing up. Words won't prepare you for how small this place is. You wouldn't believe me, so I won't belabor the point. Suffice it to say, it's small. Real small. But that's the appeal.

There are all sorts of domestic and imported beers. While there, I drank an Australian beer (IPA; light) and some Eastern European beer (Czech? I can't remember; it was dark in color like a stout but it wasn't as heavy as a stout). Wow. I am overwhelmed by the usefulness of this review. Apologies. In any case, the beers are all in a bathtub full of ice behind the bar. Awesome. The owner/barkeep can give you great details about all the brews, but still. Bathtub. Full of ice. Win.

Spending an hour and a half or so here made me feel like a bona fide San Franciscan. It was a terrific re-introduction to the city by the bay. I didn't see a Black Horse. I might have seen a cherry tree. Woo hoo. I definitely saw a Londoner. And, I was in a pub. So, I guess the name of the bar makes sense -- which is more than I am doing now. What am I saying? Uh, come here to drink beer out of bathtub and battle claustrophobia. A word of warning, though: resist the urge to do anything concerning the numbers 1, 4 and 6. Don't ask why or what, just resist. Trust me. My wallet is thinner for having stared into that abyss.
author: Johnny T.

description:
I have never been in a bar like this. After wandering around Union Street for a while, my husband and I wanted to get off our feet and relax with a beer. When we walked in and saw how tiny it was, and how there seemed to be no seats available, we almost left. But we were coaxed in an almost surrealistic way, "Come in, come in, there's always room." Two people gave up their seats for us, which we felt bad accepting... but then after more people came in, we learned that that's the tradition: give up your seat for new people entering (especially women, which as a women made me feel slightly uncomfortable). Everyone seemed like good friends, but after being invited into the conversations, we found that most people had only met there. We stayed for 1-2 hours, talked to so many different people (including the bartender, who was amazingly nice), and had so much fun. Seriously - we're living in the Mission right now and are considering a move next year to a different part of the city, and the location of Black Horse London Pub may affect our decision. Best bar experience ever.

(Btw, I noticed other reviewers saying claustrophobics shouldn't come here... I am claustrophobic and did freak out slightly when I saw the place. But I made sure to sit close to the door and was perfectly fine. Although, I was there on a Saturday afternoon and not an evening, so I don't know how crowded it gets later on. When I was there, all seats were filled with about 3 people standing).
author: Tessa S.

description:
Stopped in here for the novelty of it being the smallest bar.  The beer price was not as small though.  For you non smokers beware, they sometimes smoke inside.  And the place is so tiny, the smoke does not disperse by the time it reaches you.  

Everyone is extremely friendly here.  So do not hang out here if you dont wanna conversate and be left alone with your drink.  Come here when you need people to talk to because you will definitely find someone to yap your heart out to.
author: Kat K.

description: Tiny bar, but lots of fun and good beer.
author: T S.

description: What a delight! Do not hesitate stopping by, just a sincere pleasure with the bartender and owner!
author: Brendan P.

description: My new buddy Patrick said it best, " my favorite bar because you have no choice except to meet the people around you." The smallest, coolest bar.  James is a great owner. We loved the tight quarters, the bathtub full of beer, the food menu (strip of bacon and cheese plate), and everything else
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Things that are larger than the Black Horse:

-A '68 VW Bug
-Verne Troyer's trouser snake
-An iPod Nano
-The amount of words in Jay Cutler's vocabulary besides "you know." http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L9WCPxDYBjg
-The dollar amount currently resting in my bank account ($3.77)
-A stapler 
-15 adult midgets in a hot tub
-This dog http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LmN_m7F9C7Y
-George W. Bush's 19% approval rating in 2008

Hopefully by now, you have an idea of what I'm talking about. The Black Horse is officially the smallest bar on the West Coast, and the owner suspects it's actually the "Smallest bar west of the Mississippi." That term gets tossed around with more regularity than a Tiger Woods one night stand, but in this instance, I think it could be accurate. At capacity, the joint holds 22 people, and according to James, the owner of Black Horse, the most they've ever had inside at any given point was 25. That may sound like an extremely small amount of people, but to call this place diminutive is an understatement.

It's been said previously, but if you're a shut-in who hates people, it'd be a smart move to avoid this place at all costs. Due to the lack of square footage and available seating, you're forced to become BFFs with the other bar patrons real fast. For those lonely nights when a dark corner and a stiff drink are the only thing that'll suffice, go elsewhere - trust me.

They only serve beer (out of a bath tub) and they enforce their bar rules with the heavy hand of a supreme court judge. By no means will you be sentenced to execution for violating the laws of this itty-bitty London Pub, but you'll be politely asked to avoid using your cell phone and you'll have to prove that chivalry is not dead by vacating your seat if women outnumber men inside the bar. So if you're the kind of guy that has no manners, and you can't resist checking Twitter from your Crackberry for more than 15 minutes at a time, you might be better off trekking a few more blocks to get tipsy in the Marina. As guilty as I might be in regards to being a slave to my iPhone, it's a relief to suspend day-to-day activities and reliance on technology to enjoy a few good brews with strangers (A.K.A., friends you just haven't met yet), in a truly remarkable setting.

If you're checking out the place for the first time, like any bar in the city, do your best to venture out on a weekday. Weekends can be an absolute disaster, and this isn't the kind of place that has a high turnover rate for bar goers. Once folks get comfy, they're usually in for the long haul.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
Great place to have a cold beer that was chilled in a bathtub behind the bar. The hostess/bartender/waitress is a sweetheart. Warm feeling in the pub-style closet. 

Last night they had bacon-wrapped hot dogs, green flash beer, and playoff baseball on the TV. I was a happy man. 

Simple place, good people, cold beer. I'll be back.
author: Jonathan F.

description: Great place to catch the Browns play or to just hang out with friends. My friends and I consider this place a standard for any Sunday NFL watching.
author: Sean B.

description: Awesome little Bar, not your typical place.  Go here for the experience and the great service.  I went here with a few friends, which our group took up most of the seats in this place.  They did only have 5 choices of beer, but its probably the smallest bar you will ever go to.  The bartender was so awesome, really engaged in conversation with you, but not forgetting to keep the beers coming if you want them.  I highly recommend to go check out this little gem, like I said, not for the beer, but for the experience.
author: Brandon T.

description:
As I walked into this itsy, bitsy, tiny pub, I was greeted by James. I introduced myself and for the remainder of the night, he addressed me by my name, which was cool. 

The place was packed, so all the seats were occupied. The pub has a rule about occupying seats. If the pub is packed and you are a male with a seat, you must sacrifice your seat to a standing female, which is cool. I don't mine giving up my seat to an attractive female...hehe.

The beer was good. I forgot which one I had, but it was $7; most expensive beer available in the pub.

Overall, the pub was an okay experience. I would go back again, but next time I would avoid the Yatzee games that goes around the pub as I witnessed some shady stuff with the payout and just enjoy the beer.

Cheers!
author: Suefow S.

description: Become a regular who moves away to have your 4th grade picture hung on the wall. Otherwise make sure you're in before midnight otherwise the deli master has to lock up shop.
author: Amy V.

description:
Cool, intimate, beer pub with laid back people sipping on great beers kept on ice in a bathtub behind the tiny bar! 

They have a "no cell phone allowed" rule which is awesome because it keeps out the annoying Marina Douch-a-b@gs talking nonstop on their phone.

Owner, James, is awesome. He's debonair, tells sensational stories and andhe's the epitome of gravitas. I heard he once owned a bar in Aspen.

I'm a girl and had a huge crush on the female bartender. I go back just to watch her take  caps off of bottles. Soooo sexy!
author: Taylor C.

description: We ended up here as tourists looking to watch the sunset, and I found this bar on yelp. Very tiny bar with a lot of character, and the owner and regulars were very nice. They serve Dogfish head 90 min IPA which was a surprise bc this is a delaware beer. There is a claw foot bathtub behind the bar as the ice chest. Lots of character. Good time!
author: Julie S.

description:
Legitimately, may be my favorite bar of all time. The experience is just so unique yet 100% authentic that you cannot help but loving it. I was in SF for work, asked yelp where to go and it sent me here. James, the owner, is a riot and welcomed me to his bar with shots of Jameson from the bottle he brought in (nothing besides beer is sold). Then the bartender bought pizza for the bar and I won $40 in a dice game. 

This is the no BS bar you have been looking for that is full of great people and is sans posers. Actually, it's more of a social club than a bar because everybody in there knew each other except me. 

Cannot recommend this place more!
author: Brian F.

description: Chill bar, visiting from So. cal Friendly atmosphere..
author: Eric J.

description: Adorbs! Cute little spot with interesting selection of beers stored in a giant bathtub. Not my favorite beers but def a fun pub to stop in.
author: Cec D.

description: Great little bar owned by James. He is a genuine entertainer and good guy. Beer selection is in a bath tub behind the bar, so that's it, but they have good beers for $5 per bottle. The bar is so small that you'll start talking to people because they are that close, but thats what makes it a cool bar!!!
author: Sylvia V.

description:
This is a true hole in the wall - I'm guessing it's the smallest pub in SF.  Driven by plenty times - finally made it in one afternoon before it was full.  The bartender was very friendly - there was one draft and he didn't think it was something we may like but hubby and I both liked it.  With that, it was an extremely generous pour...more than a pint and we even got a small refill.  While there, we met a couple regulars and a visiting Brit who truly enjoyed a home away from home.

Other bottled beers are stored in an old bathtub w/ ice - it's like a frat house party but cooler.

Good times...
author: Gloria H.

description:
Let's get one thing straight. If you don't like what you read about this place, do not bother coming. As a regular at this spot, this is a breathe of fresh air in the neighborhood.

Basics:
1. James is the soul of the bar. Cassandra is his partner in crime.
2. Bar closes at 12midnight. Best time to arrive is around 10:30pm and join the bar in a crawl to Black Magic Voodoo Lounge or Shanghai Kelly's.
3. Only beer served (from a bathtub). Options change on a rolling basis. Expect $5 a beer so I recommend coming a bit buzzed.
4. Women get chairs. Most nights are standing room only. Get to know the people around you.
5. No talking on your cell phone. Period.

Love this place. Could be the only redeemable bar left on Union Street. Great spot to roll up with a girl as the place is one of a kind.
author: Dave C.

description: This is a great place to post up before or after a meal. As others have said, you have no choice but to socialize and meet everyone else in the bar. Fine selection of beers served straight from the tub.
author: Laura N.

description: Very intimate and great ace to visit Johnny is a great and wonderful bartender.  It's a place to visit for sure. I will come back again....
author: Lettisha M.

description:
In town for a few days to meet friends, figured we'd go drink somewhere local.  

First reaction walking up to the Black Horse was - is this it?  Yeah its a narrow shop front - with folk sitting in the doorway.  Says Deli outside - ignore that...

The place is small - really small - very limited seating - about 6 or 7 seats, rest is standing room only.  There's definitely a blink moment when you walk in.

We walked in to a rousing chorus of Loving Feeling - whole/almost-full bar singing (yeah all ten of 'em).  This place is Intense - everyone quickly becomes neighbours/friends, you have no choice.  Also the bar staff are super friendly, its like Cheers, just much better!

The food was a communal plate of Doritos - this place is for beer and great company.  As noted elsewhere the beer is kept cool in a bath-tub of ice behind the bar - nothing on tap.  Decent beers in the tub - drank Chimay Blanche - notable Argie IPA also in there.

Come here again?  Definitely...
author: Steve B.

description: Wow, I never thought I'd enjoy a tiny tiny bar where I couldn't even get a seat. I did. I had a blast here. The people who work there are fantastic and so are the customers. Its a friendly little joint that reminds me of some of the tiny pubs I'd visit in Ireland. Nothing but good memories of my first visit. I look forward to my next.
author: Rich M.

description:
Tiny. Great beer, too. (Loves me some Anchor Summer!) The beer? It's in a bathtub behind the bar. Is that even legal? (And honestly... does anyone even care in San Fransisco?)

Probably not. 

But who effing gives a rat's butt? I like beer, and I also enjoy things that challenge the size ratio. Black Horse does both of these things: beer and tiny. Seven seats, as others have mentioned, and also, the bartender was very nice. She gave me a piece of her pistachio cherry blondie bar, which I happily ate, as I was at that point drinking on a very empty stomach. Also, the house rule? Ladies sit, and dudes give up their seats. (Whaaa? Dang...chivalry lives! And if not, you're pretty much forced out, so take that, dudes.)  

Tiny bathroom, tiny bar, big ol' bathtub full of beer -- not gin! -- and a great honest little place. Hearts.
author: Rachel F.

description: One of the coolest bars I've ever visited.  It's small, simple and a great place to hang out.  Everyone in there is getting along and having a good time.  Their beer selection is simple, delicious and rotates.  The owner, James, and his sexy bartender are very good at their jobs.  This is a place you HAVE to hit up while in San Francisco.
author: Frank G.

description:
What an awesome place. 

Yes it's tiny, and yes the beers are kinda pricey. But all of this doesn't matter when we followed an elderly gentleman in to the pub and he bought us a round of beers. Just like that! It was my first time coming here and I didn't know exactly where it was located. 

The people are friendly and entertaining. You can hear all kinds of stories and from different perspectives. The patrons and the bartender welcomes everyone who has a good attitude. 

It's a nice place to just grab a beer and soak in the characters who live in sf.
author: Connie M.

description:
My husband and I rented an apartment on Van Ness when I was coming to San Fran to photograph a wedding. I am from Canada, but my family lived in San Fran for a long while before I was born, and I've been back a number of times with them. I was so eager to explore the city on my own and had a list a mile long of things my family said I should see and do. 

Well, then I found the Black Horse London Pub and the majority of those plans got put on hold. I was yelping around our apartment and it popped up with some intruiging reviews. We walked by and it was empty. My husband, who is also Canadian but from a fairly British family line, was quickly enamoured by this tiny hole-in-the-wall pub that actually seemed, well, like a pub. (None of this So-And-So's Public Eatery crap for him). 

We did it. We walked it. Immediately James treated us like family and not for one second did we feel like everyone knew we were tourists. James, the owner, learned our names off the bat and him and the female bartender introduced us to everyone who came through the door. We stayed until closing playing the dice game and watching soccer and even went out with James and some of the more die-hard regulars after closing. 

SO all our plans for big dinners out turned in to ordering pizza to this bar. We loved it. I would live in it if I could. As you've probably already read, the beer is in a bathtub and James picks up more as it starts to run out. James also makes food as needed for people to enjoy. And he had a good laugh when I though he put out peanut butter and crackers and ended up with a mouthful of mustard. It seats maybe 8 and perhaps another 10 standing, which just adds to the already huge amounts of charm. It's perfect. 

They will take you in and welcome you like you've probably never been welcomed. And I am from Canadian - by and far considered to be uber polite - and I was blown away by the hospitality. 

James - we don't stop telling people about your pub. We loved San Fransisco too, but the greatest discovery was your pub. We will be back as soon as we can.
author: Kate H.

description: We found this little pub tonight after searching for local pubs nearby out hotel. We were thoroughly impressed. As soon as we walked in we felt like we were home. The atmosphere is perfect for tourists. You walk in off the street and you are welcomed with open arms. The staff go above and beyond. Good drinks. Cheap drinks. Friendly chats with the regulars make this place worth going to every night. We can't wait to go back.
author: Tegan S.

description:
Don't come with more than 4 friends, you'll break the max capacity limit! Great pub with great fare and friendly staff. 
or
Like "Cheers" but smaller...
author: C. H.

description: The interior dimensions of this pub are 7.5 feet wide x 23 feet long! This implies an extra layer of cosiness to everything that guarantees a memorable experience capped off with a most endearing owner. Cheap bottled beer plucked from an ice laden bath tub must surely rank as one of those only in the twilight zone experiences as you rub shoulders with the masses and gaze around at the flotsam and jetsam adorning the walls. Lots of pleasant chit-chat amongst the ever changing every type of age audience combined with the occasional guffaw at the tinted glass Google Bus stopping right outside to deposit hordes of millenials who as legend has it have never stopped in for a quick one!
author: Ian M.

description:
If you are in San Francisco there is no reason why you shouldn't go to this bar.

This is old school before Mixologist came and ruined my dining experience by giving me a funny look when all I asked for was a Jack and Coke.

No I don't want your award winning Sapphire Rose Martini that you concocted while the rest of the world was actually doing something that matters.

So if you like Old School bars with rules that society forgot and should remember...well...this is the place for you.
author: Cliff F.

description:
I may have peaked.  The Black Horse may be one of the coolest bars I and only ten other people have squeezed themselves into.

To call this place a hole in the wall would make people think that a hole is bigger than it really, really is. The fact that it is only 250sq feet big is in total adds to the charm of this bar that insists on no cellphones, cash-only and stools reserved for the ladies only. 

People who aren't fans of bumping up against strangers should probably stay away.   You'll end up talking to people, while having your personal space zone invaded like no other time in your life.  The prices are great, the bartenders are fantastic and you'll have a wonderous time. Just make sure you brush your teeth.
author: Mike M.

description:
So to be honest, I only came here because I thought this Pub had a pretty cool name. 
A few friends and I were brainstorming the other day of Pubs around the city we havnt been to. When someone proposed the Black Horse, we all agreed - saying that the name sounded pretty cool.

The first thing you notice when your there is how small the venue is. Most of the people there were standing, and if your lucky enough to find a seat, you HAVE (its their bar rule) to give it to a lady. 
Another one of their rules is that you cant be on your phone (talk/test) in the bar, which is a freaking awesome rule! It forces your to socialize and not be anti-social and buried in your texting world. 

Despite the venue being really small, the crowed itself is freaking awesome. Everyone there (including the bartenders and staff) are really friendly, and will often engage you in conversation seeing that you are banned from using your phone.

Botton line, awesome bar. I wish it was just a little bigger =)
author: Corey W.

description:
This may be one of the tiniest drinking holes that I have ever imbibed in...not a bad thing?

Love the Chimay, love the dice, love the tight spaces.

If you love brew and a laid back vibe...this is the place for you.

No frills. No cash. No space.

Good times.

The end of my teeny tiny review.
author: Marcia M.

description:
I love this bar because I respect places that respect themselves enough to make you work a little bit for their services. I respect their set of written rules that would ideally be unwritten rules in any good bar (i.e. No talking on cell phones [texting OK], guys who are sitting have to give up their seats to women who are standing, etc.), and believe that those rules are one of the ways a bar this tiny can work so beautifully. I love that they serve their awesome selection of beers out of a bathtub, because it makes me feel like I'm in a speakeasy back in the bad old days when booze was illegal and actually had to be made IN a bathtub. I love that the bartenders are the type of guys who will let a neighborhood regular run a tab, and who can be good-natured when telling your goofball brother-in-law when he's being a dumbshit. True pioneers of the I.B.V. (Ideal Bar Vibe).

Cash money only.
author: Trav W.

description: As small as they all say, but quaint means that you get to really get to know your new found friends. This place houses regulars for the most part, all the folks that I saw seemed to know each other however they all were very welcoming and interested in the new faces that try to fit in the joint. The fact that its cash only keeps the douches out, which makes it a place to gravitate towards. Go.
author: Matthew L.

description: good beer, laid back place, good to stop in on week days - not too busy either. so small, so hard to come with big group, but intimate enough to have good conversation.
author: Sara N.

description:
Hands down my favorite bar in SF. Thank you to Ruggy for showing me and Tiff this freakin awesome joint with it's rad owner/bartender and really really cool clientele. Seriously, every time I've gone here, I've had an absolute blast and met people I thought were totally awesome. And I always get to show this place to friends when they come into town and blow their mind completely out of their head. 

Awesomeness incarnate!
author: Nicholas N.

description: My neighborhood spot. Whatever I say about this place would not do it justice...James the owner and the vast majority of the people who work here are super friendly and courteous. And the House Rules absolutely Rule!
author: Anny P.

description:
We met James through a friends wedding and he immediately treated us like family. I fancy myself a well traveled barfly and this is one of the coolest places I've ever been to.  It's small and cramped and cant hold more than 15 people.  It's perfect.

If you want a cool place to grab a strange brew and a unique experience, this is your spot.
author: Cody V.

description:
This is a nice little different type of bar, very small, bUt with it's own atmosphere, which I really liked. If you look up Irish Bars on yelp it comes up, no I have no idea why? other then Americans famous lack of knowledge of geography, LONDON IS IN ENGLAND, Ireland is another country, thank you very much.
Any way, I liked it a lot, I should say at this stage that the beer in the bathtub is bottled, and not served draft-wise straight from the tub by a hairy arsed Englishman.
So go here, you'll really like it.
author: Paula M.

description:
Love this bar. James would be considered a bar god in Greek times. He is fun, witty, and charming. I took my best friends here after reading a review on yelp.
