We went back the NEXT weekend and we were having so much fun with James that he closed the bar and we all went to an after party on Polk Street.  It is literally the smallest bar I have ever been in; if you don't meet someone new in here you are definitely in the wrong district.  No cell phones and he means business, so don't even try. 

I was sad when I went back a few weekends ago and it looked like the silicone yuppie marina types were having a birthday party here.  I hope they haven't discovered the true greatness of the place because it would ruin the ambiance it has.
author: Jessica R.

description:
My friends have been going here quite a while, and finally Friday seemed like the appropriate day for me to see what the big deal is about. As you've probably noted from other reviews, it is probably the smallest bar you've ever been to. Mayyyybe 20 people can cram themselves into this place...maybe less.

There was a single beer tap, no liquor of any type to be seen, and I think they keep the beer in a bathtub of ice. 

Somehow, this odd combination of size and simplicity produces a very friendly environment that encourages people to meet and talk to strangers. The bartender is a super nice guy, and makes you feel right at home.

I wish it was closer to where I lived.
author: Jordan C.

description:
I put an extra star because of Chimay and smallness.

There are only 7-8 seat.  Sometime I really want to drink in small place like here.  It is better to finish your dinner at the othet place.  There is almost no food in here because too small.

The one cup of Chimay after the dinner is really good!
author: Hiroko S.

description:
This is James King's place
(chivalrous proprietor).
Beer and brains collide!
author: Nathan K.

description:
I love this place.  James is the coolest bartender and I wish I could remember her helper, who kept my chimay glass full.

THis is an outstanding bar where they keep their beer in the bathtub filled with ice, play chess and dice with you. I met a lovely young lass there as well...truly an outstanding place.
author: Blake t.

description:
When people try to describe how small a place is, they are sometimes given to saying, "There's not enough room to swing a cat." With the Black Horse London Pub, such a remark would not be an exaggeration. This hole in the wall pub/deli on Union Street near Van Ness Avenue can comfortably seat about eight people but frequently holds many more. The record, according to the owner, is 53 people stuffed into this tiny beer room. Even with as few as a dozen drinkers, you find yourself becoming physically intimate with your neighbors, and any journey to the restroom invariably involves making new friends along the way.
This scenario could go horribly wrong in so many ways if it wasn't for the genteel and sociable clientele and the bonhomie of the good-natured bartenders and owner, James King, who welcomes every new arrival as if they were a long-lost friend. If King or the bartender somehow misses greeting you, there's a good chance that one of the other patrons will extend a warm welcome. We began this crawl at Tommy's Joynt, which proclaims "Welcome strangers," but Black Horse is in a different league altogether. 
Black Horse isn't so much a pub as it is a cool rec room, with a flat screen television perched at a neck-straining angle at the corner of the ceiling; a dart board on the wall hanging precariously close to the rest room; and a bathtub full of ice and beer behind the bar. The wall is decorated with pictures of Prohibition-era beer protesters ("We want beer") and soccer scarves. Since the Blackhorse is, after all, a London Pub, it can perhaps be forgiven for prominently displaying a blue Chelsea scarf.
On one recent visit during March Madness and right after St. Patrick's Day, the white porcelain, claw-footed beer tub was full of Guinness, Smithwicks, Harp and Corona. Also nestled in the ice were some lovely bottles of Chimay Reserve, which matched the vibe perfectly. 
After an hour or so, beer reinforcements arrived in the person of Marin Brewing Company Head Brewer Arne Johnson, who brought along a keg of his excellent cask conditioned IPA, which King generously poured into a large mug. Between popping open bathtub bottles and pouring Marin IPA, King was busy preparing cheese platters to nosh on with the beer.
Black Horse might not have the biggest beer selection, but that's not the point of this unique "snug." At the Black Horse, it's all about the vibe and the camaraderie, with beer serving as a vital social lubricant. Even the injunction against cell phones seems designed to encourage real social interaction with your fellow revelers.
Cow Hollow is full of pretentious pubs and bars that attempt to create a friendly drinking atmosphere. Most of them fail miserably, and it all comes across as phony and artificial. James King could give them a master's class on the technique of a being proper publican; when you're in the Black Horse, you're in his house and, at least for the evening, part of the family. All in all, Black Horse London Pub is a delightful exercise in social interaction at its finest and one that must be experienced at least once as part of the city's vibrant, eclectic pub scene.
author: chuck l.

description:
As mentioned by others, the space is small and often times standing room only.  I prefer to drop by after a walk with my Pupkins - What I love about this place is they let the Pupkins come in and hang out with their mom while their mom throws a few back.  The beer selection is fantastic (my favorite ~ Chimay BLUE - which they were out of this past Sunday; the shame of it all considering this bar is the only bar in SF that has the biggest account with Chimay).  

And as mentioned by others, because of the tightness in space, folks are friendly and are happy to engage in conversation.  And yes, there appears to be an unspoken rule; men do offer their seats to the ladies.  Ahh, chivalry is not dead - a refreshing reminder of that men can and will be gentlemen despite the social pressures of living in a small metropolis where the standard is brawling and fighting amongst one another for the most ridiculous of things.  Folks here do not lack virtue or politeness.  

So if you're one of those people who are awkwardly social, grumpy and confrontational (and doesn't like Dogs), this place is NOT for you.
  
If you are a person who appreciates meeting strangers and engaging conversation, and don't mind being courteous to others, this place IS for you.
author: Cris B.

description:
Great spot, good beer, fun crowd. Not too Marina and the limited seats make it easier to decide if you want to hang or not. I have always had fun here. 

Shout out to Frenchie, Scott and the East coast Westchester gangstar.
author: Doreen D.

description:
This is a great neighborhood spot, where anything goes, and everyone truly gets to know your name. For what it lacks in size, it makes up for in it's welcoming atmosphere, great beers, and friendly patrons.

I really enjoy this pub. Sometimes it's quiet, sometimes it's rip-roarin' loud and I need 2 Chimay Blue's to join the party. I was there last Sunday for the Canada vs. USA Hockey game, and it was a GREAT time. 

My only complaint is that sometimes my husband "loses track of time" there and comes home late for dinner....I suppose that's a trait of a really good pub.
author: adrienne l.

description:
Are you kidding?
Visiting my buddy George in San Francisco, all weekend long he kept talking about his favorite bar.
With every intention to make it there, Friday and Saturday just didn't pan out.
Finally after a day at Danny Coyles, it was time to check out Georg's favorite watering hole.
The second we walked up I stopped to laugh, knowing now exactly why its his favorite. The place is fucking tiny!
If memory serves me right, there was just enough room for 5 bar stools, a small bar, a bathtub full of ice (where they serve the beer from), and a broom closet sized restroom. There wasn't any room left for even someone to fart.
I had a really good time enjoying the beers with the company we had, but when a few more couples crammed in, then a couple of dogs started  pushing their way around, claustrophobia kicked in.
It was time to leave.
An awesome place to get really acquainted with your neighbor on the bar stools next to you.
author: Noel J.

description:
Oh man, this place totally rocks, one of the best bars in the city. If you don't mind getting cozy with your fellow San Franciscans, I highly suggest checking this place out with a friend on game day. And the people who show up are always fun and sociable. There's two taps in the bar that they switch out daily and the rest of the beer chills in a bathtub full of ice behind the counter. 

The bartender's are hilarious, one bartender, Scott, is a diehard San Diego Chargers fan with more sass than anyone knows what to do with. In one instance, I was telling this girl that another bartender, Liz, was my sister (don't ask me why, I have no idea) so the girl walked up to ask if this was true. Without a moment's hesitation, Liz confirmed we were blood and then went on to recall memory after hilarious memory of our childhood together, it was a riot.
author: Anthony C.

description:
Great place. I like the intimate setting in the bar, and the rule that if there is a girl, a guy has to give up his seat for them. It's a great way to start conversation with people in the bar too. All very nice. 

There'll be the occasional marina-guys that end up here with his "buddies", but dont let that discourage you. Just wait for the 1-4-24 dice game.
author: Chieko H.

description: I stumbled on this place while visiting a friend in the Bay this summer.  We planned on having one drink and ended up staying for 4 hours.  It has a great atmosphere and our bartender was really nice.  I would recommend this bar to any local or traveler because it has such a unique feel.  They have the best deli sandwiches by the way!
author: Brian F.

description:
Been here many times.  It is a cool spot, great owner, great regulars, and nice scene.  It's a tight space, so if you can't mingle in close quarters, you may want to rethink it.  Highly recommend for those of you that love beer, and for those that don't...have a cider.  Someone may ask you to guess at the name of a movie, after providing hints from a movie book.  There is a lot of competition.

Oh yes - Hi James, Hi Steve, and all the others!
author: N F.

description:
really cool place to go if it's not crowded. I'd say it's the only neighborhoody sort of place around there that isn't expensive.

beer kept in a bathtub by the bar and usually one really good local beer on tap. would like to try the food but they are more about the beer.
author: Crutonic L.

description:
love the fact that the guys are only searching for dates.....what happened to this place? will only show my face if james or cassandra are there...otherwise, its a joke. fire the rude du
de from tonight...
author: debbie w.

description:
If you suffer from any claustrophobia whatsoever, then this place is not for you -- in fact, if you even know what the word means, it might not be the place for you.

Everything here is defined by the lack of space. The forced intimacy means that you pretty much have to introduce yourself and talk to whomever you're near. Hopefully, you enjoy their company, because it's basically impossible to move elsewhere to mingle.

I didn't mind the absence of privacy too much at first, but after the "nth" time that somebody says "Excuse me" as they scrape by you to get to and from the one bathroom, it got pretty tiresome.

There's no draft beer, just cans and bottles, and $3 for a PBR can is on the high side, no? 

I spotted a yellow, red, and black "Deutschland" soccer scarf high up on one of the walls, which presumably would be an absolute sacrilege in a real London pub, so I'll give the owner the benefit of the doubt and assume he lost a big bet or something.
author: Adam Z.

description:
I went to the Black Horse London Pub on Friday night for the first time with some friends....It was the best bar EVER!  Don, the firefighter was in town visiting from LA, and made the most delicious soup and tri-tip sandwiches, that he so nicely shared with us!  Everyone at the Pub, especially owner, James, and regular, Steve, were so friendly and welcoming and made our experience amazing!  

I would highly recommend this Pub as a great spot to hang out and meet some great people!
author: Candace W.

description:
This place is really cool. small, cute, has a lot of character. 

The reason I only gave it two stars is because of the bartender.
I won't leave a name because I don't want to get her in trouble but..

I can't believe the owners of this bar would hire someone who is clearly coked out of her mind, complete with twitchy jerkey movements. 

Oh, and did i mention that this was during the daytime? Unacceptable.
author: sam s.

description:
On the advice of sir Ruggy (who has never yet set me astray), I came down here for some mid-sketchfest booze to keep the day flowing if ya know what I mean. 

Me and a friend walked into the place with no one else in there, but then again there are really only one kind of people that you find in a bar @ 2PM on a beautiful Saturday...professional drunkards. I was pretty impressed at the beer selection - there wasn't a ton of them, but they were all well thought out...and sitting in a bathtub. The prices were perfectly reasonable too - I think Chimay was on the high end and ran you $7. The bartender knew his stuff too - the beer recommendations were top notch.

This place is teh win (and got the 5th star) for really exactly one super reason tho - the awesome peeps that go there. No scene. No pretention. Just a bunch of easy going people wanting to talk about shit and drink some delish beer. Doggies allowed. Cell phones not. Seats have to be given up for the ladies (damn chivalry) if need be. Oh yeah, and watch your head when you get up from sitting on the poo poo machine - you'll smack it on the towel dispenser if you aren't careful (I did...even though there is a giant sign on it warning you of this fact).

I think I must have talked to everyone in there (I'm serious...because that was only like 7 people by the end of the night) about awesomeness and life in general - a history of schwinn bicycles to an awesomely kind gentleman with a handlebar moustachio, and the shitiness of New Jersey to someone else who escaped that wretched hell hole a long time ago (just like me!). 

Really, this is a great place to go to hang out with a cool crowd and kill some time if you're bored...I'm already planning on heading over there tomorrow since I don't think I'm going to have anything else to do.
author: Sean C.

description:
I had to look through the reviews as i had never read them, but i've been going here for years. Its a sleepy little spot that pumps. Ultra small bar. Basically there is behind the bar and in front of the bar, and a small area for darts. Super cool spot to hang, but dont try to come here with a group. it'll never happen. The whole bar may be able to fit... 20 people? Great drink/beer selection. One of SF's (little) gems. 

I'm just wondering who is the 1 Yes vote in the survey under Coat Check???
author: Adam X.

description:
Charmed.  I am absolutely charmed.   If this pub asked me to dinner, I would blush and giggle and then run out to buy a new outfit and maybe even a pretty bra (because I'm thinking you are totally gonna get to second, Black Horse...).   

I've been twice in the last three days.  Too eager?
author: L W.

description:
Do you live in a teeny tiny studio? I'm not talking the sort where there is room for a bed and a couch, plus a hallway, bathroom and full kitchen. I am talking you walk in the front door and have to step over your twin sized bed to get to the bathroom and mini fridge/ hotplate combo that the landlord qualifies as a "kitchen". 

When you start feeling claustrophobic and need to be cheered up over your cramped living quarters just pop over to the Black Horse and grab a brew. It is cozy, and by cozy I mean, you just made a new friend of everyone in the place without even trying, cozy. This little pub will make your place look like the Taj Mahal.

On the upside it is owner operated and will allow you, legally, to smoke inside. Cute LITTLE place.
author: Drue C.

description:
Pure. Genius.  Words fail to describe the eccentricity and magic of this one-of-a-kind surreal bar experience.  

First of all there's the mythology and cult appeal -- James, originally from Cleveland (who he describes is a good place to "be from" but not "be at") bought the place (originally a deli shop, and still is by the books) almost 20 years ago and has been running the unusual shotgun establishment since.  From the moment he says hey you'll love the guy.  Well, unless he's kicking you out for being on your cellphone -- no phones allowed!  (Texting is ok though).  Due to the zoning "as a deli" he's forced to close at 12pm and can only serve beer.  Not that he'd like it any other way, I'm sure.  James is the man.

The venue reminds me of the 7 1/2th floor in Being John Malkovich.  It is wedged between businesses like an earthquake or large construction vehicle played an unfortunate fate to its size.  Yet it adds so much to its appeal.  To stand in the Black Horse is an experience in an of itself.  Once inside you'll see that there's a vintage bathtub housing a keg of Caske Ale (1 of 2 only places that serve it) through a ghetto-rigged hose on a hand pump tap.  The rest of the tub serves as a colorful odorous trash bin for beer bottles.  What a sight!   

The rumor is if the barstools were removed 50 people can fit inside the place at once.  Even with only 20 or so patrons the bar seems impenetrable and intimidating for the shy passerby.  You will be bumping people, rubbing against them, apologizing, greeting, laughing, and partying with everyone in there like it or not.  There's also the matter of quirky dice games, outsourced food logistics (order a pizza to be brought here, no problem!), and the mythical cheese plater.  It has its own black board.  You will soon understand.

So what makes this place a 5-star Yelp "good as it gets" spot? 

The people.

The Black Horse London Pub is effective in autonomously repelling the kind of people that wouldn't have a good time there, so you'll be treated to some of the friendliest outgoing people that San Francisco has to offer. You cannot move past someone without getting to know them, and you'll be glad you did.  

The forced circumstances ensures great times, guaranteed conversation, bewilderment, and a warm and fuzzy sense of spontaneous stranger togetherness that you've perhaps only seen on television.  Maybe only the mythical Cheers tops this experience.

Come to The Black Horse and come often.  We will know your name.
author: niero g.

description: One of the coolest owners I've ever met.. You can tell he really enjoys what he does.. Check this place out, it's awesome!
author: Jaipal N.

description:
This bar is huge, I had a party for about 300 people here once. Oh wait, just took my medication, must have been hallucinating... Actually, if you can get 30 people in here I'd be surprised, and that's a good thing.

The Black Horse is truly that bar where everyone could potentially know your name, well at least after a few pints. Everytime I stop in, there's always someone telling a story. On the flipside, if you're talking to whomever you're with, there's a good chance that another patron will chime in with his/her own opinion.

No cell phones allowed, you'll get nasty looks, and the usually gentlemanly bartenders will ask you to leave. Don't be that guy.
author: Nish N.

description:
Hadn't been here in years but wandered by last weekend... to my surprise, still a great place with a great vibe.  Amazing how many cool people you can meet in a place that seats @10 people.
Do yourself a favor, read the rules and don't be an A#@ and you'll get along just fine here.
They have an interesting assortment of beers that seem to change regularly, the blackboard will give you the list and the bartender can fill you in on the qualities of the beer.
God times!
author: Jack P.

description:
So.... I was in a rush to get out of my apt to meet my friends at the BART. So I didn't bother reading a single thing about the Black Horse before we got off the taxi at Union & Van Ness. Hah. This was so different than what I expected, or from anything that I have EVER seen before. 

Let's start with the sign, which says "Black Horse London Deli". The place was so small, I kept expecting a "surprise! There's a hidden room in the back" revelation. Or, "surprise! This is our appendage Deli; we run the Pub behind the Deli in this big room that you were expecting." I saw the door at the end of the shop, thought it was a portal to a bigger area. It was the bathroom. And apparently there's a max volume b/c there's apartment neighbors. It is nuts how small this place is. I don't think I've seen one of those small restaurant crevices this small. Those things have room in the back for more space.

Friendly people who don't give a trap about being bigger. The novelty wore off pretty fast, and we played some 1-4-24. That was it. The can likely distinguish the regulars and the occasional tourist. But nothing was made of your strangeness; instead, they were quick to explain the game, and the beer, and what's going on.

I cannot believe this place can exist. And I think I would enjoy this place, but alas I am moving. I think I would up their rating to a 5 if I stayed in the Bay.
author: Andrew S.

description:
My New Year's Resolution was to spend more time in this bar.  


With a sea of bros in mesh trucker hats swallowing my neighboring Russian Hill bar scene whole, it's nice to come to a place that is down to earth enough to keep beer on ice in a bath tub behind the bar.
author: Sarah J.

description:
Def. worth a visit!  I was a stranger in a strange land when I first moved to SF and after a day of rollerblading, I was hungry and thought I'd pop in for some food (Their sign includes the word "Deli").  I was absolutely delighted by this very quaint bar, and lively crowd.  I knew I had stepped into a gem. Kinda like one of those off the beaten path finds except that it's literally 2 blocks from mi casa.  On this day, I'd forge a friendship with one of my closest friends.

1)  I love how the men are required to give up their seat for you. 
2)  I love that it is small, and that it is easy to make conversation and new friends
3)  I love James - he's just a cool cat
4)  I actually love their charcuterie plate: with stinky cheeses and meats. - I'm unsure but I don't think they serve this anymore.
5)  Dog friendly

My neighborhood local watering hole, bring cash.  Beaware of Chimay's after 2 or 3 - you will be certainly buzzed if not, drunk.  ;-)
author: Sheila W.

description:
"Small pub, big heart" perfectly embodies The Black Horse. Regarded by me and my friends as "the smallest pub on earth" (likely not, but I care not about any smaller). 

James and crew clearly enjoy tending bar here and who can blame them? They make this place what it is, along with everyone else who appreciates it.

Couldn't think of a place more worthy of my 100th review. I've shared 100s of beers and 100s of laughs with 100s of people and 100s of  well spent dollars in my years visiting this fine pub. I've been here during an earthquake when people outside felt it and we didn't. I've seen a dog dressed as superman and a man dressed as super woman. I've cried...tears from laughing so hard. I've taken a glass home (on accident)  and brought it back for a free refill (don't recommend this one). I've jumped into the back seat of a stranger's car at the gas station across the street and got taken home. And will continue to have many stories to share with time.
author: Mike C.

description:
I came here for the first time last night and it's a really cool place. James was bartending and he's a really friendly guy. I tried the Kasteel Cru -- a French beer fermented with champagne yeast. It tasted very similar to champagne and nothing like any beer I'd tried before. 

The only disappointing aspect of my experience is they didn't have any beer on tap. They usually do, just were out on that particular night. I'll definitely be back here again for good times and draft beer.
author: Aaron V.

description:
I lived in London - I know pubs. This a real one, not that crappy "ye olde English pub" (which is actually everywhere in England) but a real London style pub. They even have yummy pub grub - like ploughman's lunch - even had stilton. 

The Real DEAL!
author: Danger A.

description:
Sometimes its hard to feel like "Mr. Big" in this city- you know what I mean, you walk into the bar, and the sum total of every client looks up at the new stranger coming in with a look of well....drunken happiness. 

well, this is definately the place. WIth an awesome beer selection (double points for the chimay blue and quad points for the spaten Oktoberfest) and the cheese/chutney plate was to die for. And with the place being so small, there's no way you could not make friends with everyone in the bar in say, 5 minutes....which can be a bad thing if you do like I did and agree to play the sadistic (but cheery) bar staff  a game that is a crazy mix of simon says combined with tazer technology, and if you lose then......yeah, it must have been the beer......

be warned, cell phone technology- unlike tazer-enabled simon says games- are frowned upon muchly!
author: Tim V.

description: This is a locals' treasure. If you are new to SF and live in the Marina or Russian Hill and don't know anyone - pull up a bar stool (if you are lucky there are any left) and get to know your neighbor. The owner James is a gem. He is so sweet and genuine. You are forced to speak with everyone in the bar since it is so small and no cell phones usage is allowed. Genius! If you use it you will be put in time out - not kidding. We need a technology slap in the face once in a while and especially at your local watering hole!
author: Laura A.

description:
Oh, I love it.  I love interesting beer, and tiny crowded spaces, and unpretentious bars. I even love the fact the beer comes from a bathtub. (I didn't think I would love this, but I do!)

 Next time, I will:

1. Not come with a guy friend I haven't seen in awhile, because (as others have pointed out), this is a prime place to chat with strangers and not so ideal for a one-on-one conversation

2. Not be such a girly-girl and order myself a cheese plate right from the start

3. Get a little wasted and join in the heated dice game going on in the "back" of the bar (maybe a scant five feet away from the front)
author: Chelsea R.

description:
Obviously opinions change continuously...
After visiting the smallest bar in the city for the second time, but this time actually being able to enter made all the difference. 

The one bartender is personable and welcoming. How could you not be when you are 2 feet from each other at all times. Conversation was good and the idea of the place made me feel more comfortable. 

I'd recommend coming here on week night. I wouldn't recommend ordering a cheese platter (the only dish they offer) I don't know how it could be sanitary to eat in the little joint, but a beer and laughs is just fine.

______________________________________________
my original 2 star review:
I'm stuck in a box and there's no way out........
I admit I haven't been inside. I have walked by it numerous times and I cant fit and if I could I'd be stuck between eeks a mouse and a dirty bar stool. Smallest Bar in SF, what is cool about that?
How can you run a business out of a closet. I wonder what rent is... One star for still being open after a billion years 
One star for trapping customers (I don't know how you do it, but it's something to be proud of)
author: Dee C.

description:
After years of walking past this place and wanting to give it a try, I finally got the chance!  A friend organized a small group of us to stop in here on a recent Friday night for happy hour.  I was worried we wouldn't all be able to fit, but we managed.  I love the rules this place has, #1: no talking on cell phones (texting is okay), #2: men must offer their seat to ladies.  The bartender/owner, James, made it a point to learn everyone's name, which is very touching and made me feel at home here, even though it was my first time in the bar.

A small yet varied selection of bottled beers is available out of an ice bucket in a bathtub, and all are reasonably priced.  If you are really watching your wallet, there is always the $3 PBR ($2 at happy hour).

A tiny space but I had a great time here.  Chatted with my friends and met a few of the regulars, and I look forward to coming back again soon!
author: Lindsay B.

description: Maybe I should have gone to this bar with a different perspective but with 5 stars from so many Yelpers I thought this place would be amazing.  Don't get me wrong, its a cool place where your beers are served from a bathtub but its really small.  You can barely walk by people.  The staff is cool but I had a hard time understanding who was a bartender from the people behind the bar.  As a 6'4" person I need a little more room to walk around and chat with people.  Otherwise a bar with a lot of personality.
author: David H.

description:
There is a tiny bar in Tampa, called Fuma Bella.   I though it was the smallest bar ever, until I came here.  

This is also one of the coolest bars I've ever been in, but be prepared for cramped quarters.   The entire place is about 10 feet by 20 feet, about the size of the bedroom in your house, but full of character.  

Seats about 8 people at the small bar.   The also have a dartboard, but if there are more than about 4 people in the bar you can forget about that!

Cool bartender, I forget her name, but she was bartending while trying to pass the bar exam!   There are all sorts of lawyer/bartender jokes there, but I'll refrain.   

This is definitely my favorite bar in San Francisco, and will return next time I'm in the city.
author: Jim S.

description:
REALLY???  I've been coming here for the last 8 or so years and I have never seen such a horrible sight before in such a beautiful place...PBR cans on the bar???  WTF is up with that?  Joe (the original owner) would be sooooooooo disappointed.  They had nothing on tap and the other beer selections were nothing special.  We don't come to the Black Horse for stupid PBR (which I am a fan of and have put back many in my lifetime, but go to crap bars to drink it).  It was absolutely the saddest moment of my week when I saw the cans.  

JJ and James, please fix this.  PLEASE!!!!!!
author: Ayrn H.

description: Definitely going to back one day! Cassandra is the best! Nice little hang out spot if I still lived in the city.
author: Robert Y.

description:
Hot Dang this place is amazing! One of my favorites. As a single lady it is next to impossible to find a bar where you can have a beer on your way home and not get hassled. James and his amazing staff have solved this problem. 
P.s. If you are a game player (dice, dominos, cards, cribbage) this is the place for you!
For extra fun go see Ryan on Thursdays!
author: Sally L.

description:
True love:

Me:  "I'll have a Chimay, please."
Bartender:  "White or Blue?"
author: Ann M.

description:
Its square footage is akin to that of a walk in closet, which is sort of what made our visit extra special (once we squeezed thru the throngs of people who managed to pack themselves cozily into this hole-in-the-wall pub).

We were lucky enough to meet Dave (and his buddy Matt) before his venture out into the Galapagos Islands to keep his gf company while on a research assignment. He hooked it up with free pints of beer and cider, which only made his (and Matt's) travel conversations all the more interesting. 

By etiquette, gents aren't allowed to sit on the bar stools if a woman wants to sit down. Yeayuh. And I find this to be a BIG plus. Especially since we need the bar hooks for our purses/coats/and ish.

Overall - a basic, no-frills and no-nonsense pub. Great bartenders with great capacity to hold a fun and buzzed conversation!
author: Ro D.

description:
it's my life long dream to fill a bath tub with alcohol so, SOLD.

i don't even care that they only accept cash, because of course they only accept cash. they don't have a fucking refrigerator, why would they have a credit card machine.
author: J R.

description: This is a great place. If you are in town and near by its a must to visit. James is awesome and makes you feel at home right away. Great place, great people.
author: Jennifer C.

description: This place made my first trip to SF unforgettable. A cozy old fashion - talk to your neighbor - we're all here for good company- sort of atmosphere. If I recall correctly, no cell phones were permitted. Small, simple, and welcoming.. all you really need :)
author: Krystle G.

description:
When they say this bar is small, they are not kidding. Do not come here if you have "personal space issues." However, J R. is correct when she says that James is a god amongst bartenders. Truly, he is the best bartender I've ever encountered. And not just because he has a sexy accent.

My favorite thing about this bar is the fact that it is nearly impossible not to make friends. You are literally FORCED to interact with people as they climb over you (and vice versa) on their way to the bathroom. Luckily, most of the people who were here when I was were very nice... and they didn't smell bad.
author: Evann G.

description: Cutest bar ever! Tiny and charming. Five beers to choose from, four of which sit in an old ice filled bathtub behind the bar, the fifth is a cask on tap selection. Friendly proprietor, nice patrons...definitely don't bring the whole crew from the office here. If you sit near the door and stay long enough to fall of your barstool, you'll roll right into the street where the bus or a cab will surely run you over. Great place to show visitors some off the beaten path SF flavor.
author: Pam D.

description:
There are so many factors that collided to make this a 5-star review.  Let's begin!  

It was date no.2 with a semi-stranger.  On the way to drop me off, we drive by, find parking, and next thing I know we're at the door.  That's where I stopped.  It was packed, elbow-to-elbow, and there were only 5 people inside.  He assures me to just keep pushing, and sure enough, in the way back, there was room for us.  I will say, whether planned or not, the confined space was an excellent excuse for body contact.

Once in back, we hear that someone has bought a round for the bar, so we score free drinks and someone offers me a stool to sit on.  As we're drinking, a dice game is going on, and ends.  We can play in the next game for only a $1 buy-in (conveniently I had two bucks in my wallet).  

Here's where it gets even better (I know, unbelievable!).  My pal takes the shaker, rolls, and loses.  The shaker is passed to me, and after three rolls, I've WON the entire game (which might have been called One Four Twenty-Four??).  How much did I win, you ask?  A whole $14!!!  So now I'm drinking free beer and up $12!!

Now for the best part!  There is a nudie calendar of everyone who works there, complete with bios.  It was only in draft stages during my January visit, but I'm pretty sure the final version can only be better.

Additional Pros: The beers are recycled into a claw-foot bathtub behind the bar; everyone in that place is talkative and friendly; prices are super cheap.
author: Lindsay W.

description:
5 Stars = NOT ENOUGH
This place is my favorite bar in San Francisco...HANDS DOWN!!
My friend Jamie and I came here on a whim...on a what the heck, there are two stools available in an 8 stool bar...on a HOLY CRAP is that CHEESE PLATE on the One Item menu...on a what?? Is that an ice filled bath tub holding your beer ... on a Credit Cards...we don't need credit cards where we're going cuz it's cash only ADVENTURE...

Are you in need of an adventure...a small adventure...???
author: Karen B.

description:
The most unbelievable bar you'll come across on Union Street!  I really thought my eyes were deceiving me when I walked in.  The place is literally as big as a walk-in closet!  But something about those close quarters on a chilly night was very comforting.  Maybe it was the leg-cuddle I was forced to do with the cute guy on a date with an ugly girl (believe me, he was having more fun with my leg).  The owners/bartenders are great guys... but they have their rules: no cell phones unless you're in the W.C.  They were regulars of the place and after tallying more than 1000 hrs, they decided to buy it!  How do I know?  They have a time-clock and all the true regulars can get one to keep track.  Good beers and a great pear cider... but nothing more than a cheese plate at dinner time.  If you're a bar connoisseur, you've got to check this real "hole-in-the-wall" out!

Update:  I added one more star because they upgraded their menu... they now serve a salami sandwich, so you can down as many Chimay Blue's as you like and not be scared of falling off your barstool and into some guy's lap : )
author: Tara G.

description:
Very much a little local spot with fun loving local flavor. The bar is so small that if you don't have a conversation there is something wrong. 

Perfect place for Chimays... but watch out, they can creep up on you quickly.
author: Danielle V.

description: I lived in Cow Hollow for 5 years and made a trip to James' warm and welcoming cozy home every couple months.  He's turned his spot into a friendly bar where everyone knows your name and keeps interesting suds (that's beer people) inside his claw foot bathtub on ice.  If you're walking by Union Street at Van Ness, and love quaint cozy spots, be sure to stop in and say hello to check it out!
author: Dave M.

description:
FUN FUN FUN! I earned my nickname BLACK MAMBA from James the second weekend we went here. It's like a great huge party in a box (LITERALLY, with it's size) everytime!
My sister learned the how serious indeed they are about NO CELL PHONES when she was expecting a call from her husband who is in the Navy and has been away in Iraq. The did offer to let her use the office when he called but she just booked it out of the place (and this is no easy feet with people jam packed into every crevice including the front door). She left so fast that she didn't grab her jacket and I had to squeese out the front door with it in hand because I was worried she would freeze. It was still "California winter" time after all.
I love love love going to this bar. It truly gives you the authentic pub feel, while squeesing you in like a sausage!
author: Lynda O.

description: Tiny review for a tiny bar: good beer, friendly bartenders, fun atmosphere. Come visit!  (...just not all of you at once.)
author: Jennie K.

description: I love this place, run by USF Alumni James ( Elvis) and a partner.  I knew it would be great , if James had a part in this place, and it was,. It's a teeny tiny closet of a bar, but had good company , good vibe and great beer. He also had some cheese and fruit.  I had a blast along with the rest of my girlfriends.  I have been meaning to go back and will make a point of hitting up this spot this summer. Cups up to all that go!
author: Susie S.

description:
I love this bar. It is probably one of the best places to grab a beer after work. You know a bar is great when Bloomberg posts a story on it. This story was the seventh most read story on the Bloomberg professional service. I work at Bloomberg and can tell you that we NEVER write stories on bars.
Here is the story.
http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601010&sid=aSxIlW88E6no&refer=news
author: John S.

description:
This is a love story.

As big as a big closet and as cozy as Christmas morning. Chilled Chimay blue--along with a small list of other well-chosen beers--flows freely. Cheese plates all night long. The clientele seem to be undergoing an unusual, collective identity crisis, all wondering whether they belong in Berkeley or the Marina. Bartenders are friendly and so genuine. Though the Black Horse isn't quite in North Beach, drinking here made me feel like I'd stepped into old Beat San Francisco.
author: Karin H.

description:
Under any other circumstances I would of just passed this place up if I walked by; considering it looks like a closet. However, my good friend Cory was a bar back there and made the experience an awesome one for me every time I was there. All the people that come to hang out are friendly and easy to talk to. I don't drink alcohol, but was always accommodated with the special tea and crackers that Cory or James so kindly prepared for me. 

The place is TINY and I mean TINY!!! That's why I just couldn't give it five stars...
author: Crystal B.

description: This place is amazing.  On a recent visit to SF, my good friends Tiffany and Nick introduced Jared and I to this bar and I must say thank you!  I am with Tiffany on this, I do love beer but I was so full after two that I had to stop drinking.  Luckily, I had that dice game to keep me busy.  James was friendly and made sure he met every person in the bar and knew their names.  The bar was well lit, the music wasn't too loud, and you could talk to everyone in the bar.  Awesomeness.
author: Yvonne C.

description:
Consistent with other reviews; the place is tiny but the bartenders are genuine and always welcome you in.

I wouldn't go there if you're claustrophobic or mind having to squeeze by people to move around.

That being said, other than being small, this place is perfect....the only truly "Cheers-like" place in the Marina (or the city) I can think of.
author: Nate H.

description:
3.5 really

This little gem fits about 10 comfortably. The bartender was very nice, the beer even nicer but we may have had too much of a dirty gay aura about us, cuz nobdy tried to talk to us. This was after all, a night away from our beloved Dolores Park hood. I imagine that had we had a couple of seats, or a couple more rounds things would've gotten cozier.  But we had cougars to hunt and fernet shots to do in search of the uber Marina bar.

I'll definitely come back here without a cultural agenda. Gotta love a tiny but well honed European beer offering that alone deserves 5 stars.
author: G Z.

description:
Wow. This place is fantastic. I had no idea it existed until my friend suggested it the other night. The Black Horse only holds around 15 people tops, and that's what makes it so amazing. The beers of the day are kept in a bucket and the cheese plate is delicious with fruit, salami, chutney and bread. We played a gambling dice game with the bartender and a few others while the guy sitting next to me swapped great stories then bought everyone in the bar a round.

This is the friendliest, most relaxed bar I've ever been to. I've never felt more at home and had one of the best nights ever with my friend. I can't wait to go back.
author: Jessica C.

description: Best bar in the city.  Not only did I meet my wife here, but we got engaged here as well.  Go here if you want a fun local crowd.
author: Bob R.

description: Small, but awesome. Nice people! The problem is that the parking meters are expensive, and be prepared to stand. Watching games are great thought!
author: Paige H.

description:
Best "deli" ever.
Best bartenders ever.

This place seriously feels like Cheers...minus all the extra room.  Everyone always gets free shit.  The last time I was there, some guy spotted the whole place, I scored a few beers.  I love the phrase "it's on me", you seem to hear it a lot here...which is totally fine with me!

Good times, good people, good booze.  Goodness!
author: Meghan B.

description:
The Black Horse London Pub tested my will power. My favorite Comedian, Mitch Hedberg, once said, "Alcoholism is the only disease that you can get yelled at for having. Damn it Otto, you're an alcoholic! Damn it Otto, you have Lupus! One of those just doesn't sound right." 

Well, luckily I do not have Lupus, but on Sunday night I thought that someone was going to yell at me for becoming an alcoholic. If you love beer in good company, The Black Horse London Pub is a dangerous place! Like most people, I love the occasional beer. And like most, every now and then I like to test my level of consumption. Sunday night drinking has never been this much fun! 

This place is so small it's like someone threw all of their wife's shoes and jackets out of her walk-in closet. They then decided to line the walls with random artifacts, put in an actual bathtub, fill it with hard to find bottles of European beer and throw down one hella of a time! They slept on the couch for a week afterward, but damn was it worth it!
 
Because of their extremely small square footage, I can't say for sure that this place is taken from the pubs of London. I have witnessed many people getting yelled at in London for alcoholism and the yelling starts at 9am, so therefore their pubs have to be larger.

Everything about this place fits! I have never seen so much great beer being consumed with absolute glee. I have never seen so many people smiling in unison. In fact, I'm still smiling. I spoke with people that I have never seen in my life and we talked as though we were in the "shit" together, (I believe that's a war term). Be careful, the bartenders are instigators. They stand behind the bar sparking conversations with a bottle opener in hand waiting to unlock all that you are trying so hard to fight against... that one more. At this place, from this day forward, the "one more" will now be called the "3 more" (minimum). Pass it on.

Try this place right now! They're open at 4pm for those of you that may be reading this before hand. But at 4pm... Go There!

Cheers!
author: Michael R.

description:
DO NOT EVER GO TO THIS PLACE!!!

With that being said...

I love this place!  But it's TINY and gets crowded and I don't want you all to take over!  It's my place...MINE!  I stopped in the other day, walking home from shopping on Union, sweating, desperately needing a beer...

...heaven.  Krusovice...my favorite Czech beer...in a BIG bottle...

This place has got style.  And not your uber-lounge, see and be seen, style.  It's got a bathtub to chill the beers style.  And its pet friendly.  Good, that means I can bring along some of the dogs I typically end up dating.

Remember:  Don't come here!
author: Susan L.

description:
WOW, size really does matter! The smaller the bar, the better the wait.

So I walk in here and the first thing I get is, "Dude? did you read the rules?"  I'm like WTF?  "Dude, the rules, on the wall...read them".

So I read them. Hell yeah. I agree with them 100%. Order a Chimey and get to know your neighbour. 

P.S.  - Give up your seat to a lady,.....you smug S.O.B........then try to get her to come home with you.
author: Mark B.

description:
I could try to be witty about how small it is (bring your own bar stool) or make some funny pun (hole in the wall)... but let's not dwell. 
It's a fun, charming bar; complete with naughty, homemade calendars. And yes, the rumors about the cheese plate are true.
author: Meg I.

description: This place is great. Best atmosphere in any bar around, cool people, and excellent drinks like the Coopers Stout. Love it, will be back next weekend again!
author: Dan D.

description:
This may be the only place in San Francisco smaller than my studio. 

What's it got that my place doesn't? Chimay... blue and white! And bottles of beer on ice in a claw foot bathtub behind the bar. 

My fellow patrons are great... all 15 that can fit in the bar with me, and James the bartender knows every single one. The first time I came in, he knew I wasn't a regular, and made sure to introduce himself. So rare for the city! He's very attentive, and has discreetly offered to rescue me before from overly-friendly "gentlemen". 

I just hope the dartboard on the back wall is a joke!
author: Kelly C.

description:
They brag about being the smallest bar on the West coast. I don't have any reason to doubt them. Standing room is barely one person wide.

It's good place to hang out and grab a few beers. Not really a pickup joint.  They have Stella, two kinds of Chimay, and a cask on tap.

The regular crew there are pretty entertaining. Ask to see the "Men of the Black Horse" calendar. Um, actually, maybe you shouldn't...
author: Shawn T.

description:
The people that "have actually fit" into this cute (tiny) little bar know what this place is all about. Funny staff behind the bar, surprise beers all the time, and VERY VERY intimate conversation. I think this place is awesome. I only have the patience to go there sometimes but when I do - its a blast!

If you can find it - GO!
author: Jack H.

description: Woah, this place is teeny, but it was so much fun! Good thing I only came with one other person!
author: Jen M.

description:
In an area of the city maligned for it's superficial nightlife, the Black Horse stands apart.  It's the type of place that reminds you of why you live in the city... a simple pub that does everything right.

And what other bar holds a Big Lebowski party?
author: Mathew S.

description:
This bar is really REALLY small. Like I'd say only 20 people MAX can fit in here. With that being said the people here are really really nice. I love that most of the regulars sitting at the bar all had British accents ( it is a London pub, right?!).  The first thing I noticed when I walked in is the bathtub behind the bar that they use as their fridge. They fill it up with ice and keep all the drinks in it, pretty interesting and eccentric at the same time. I would come here for a drink or two with one buddy, if you are in the mood for a great conversation, or for the dice game 24 ( which I played, and WON!).

 The only reason this place isn't a 5 or 4 star bar to me, is that it is really really tiny and I also think they only serve beer, I'm pretty positive that there isn't a full bar, and if there is WHERE are they hiding it?!
author: Sarah T.

description: The Horse is awesome.  If you don't  like awesome people and a guaranteed good time, you should probably keep walking.  Also, James is great :-)
author: Kyla B.

description:
The cheese plate is amazing. Great local spot to go and have a few, strong beers with a good friend. You usually meet some really nice folks too. 

Oh and they have rules posted on the wall that you can't use a cell phone and men must give up their seats for the ladies. Gotta love it!
author: Shannon C.

description:
We feel so proud of ourselves for finally having a drink at this place. We loved the euro-beers, loved James, loved the tiny tiny bar...and the fact that he has an Edward Gorey book propped up on the wall above the bar just sold it for me.  
And now for the icing on the cake: it is a dog-friendly bar!!!!
I think we just found a new bar. 
yay.
author: Nilu r.

description:
What a shock this place is located where it is!  

Everyone talks to everyone.  It feels like the neighborhood-y place you'd hang out in if you worked in a textile mill and had to drink to cope every night... no, here, they drink to enjoy the company.  Wholly different.

The guys who work the place are genuinely friendly.  I will return with friends soon before we retreat to someone's place in order to beat ROCK BAND.  Double true!
author: Paul C.

description:
It's tiny, it's fun, and there's always great beer available. James (the owner) is one of those people who, if you study him a bit, you see that he is living out his dream of owning a pub and is proud of the place. Yes, there are rules, and that is a good thing. Otherwise things could become unmanageable in this place. Yes, you are forced to talk to people you don't know. Which is again a good thing (most of the time).

The atmoshphere is welcoming and what a true neigborhood bar should feel like. It's like that Cheers-like feeling, but grounded in reality and not on television but in real life.

Hats off to owners James and JJ, as well as Chris the bartender.
author: Tolga E.

description:
Very nice bartenders, decent music, cozy little room and friendly and cool customers.

I'd go 5 stars if not for the sliiiiiiiightly overpriced beers. $5 for a 12 ounce Newcastle is a bit pricey, but that aside, this is a great little spot. I will absolutely be returning.
author: K F.

description:
The Black Horse is a gem. A diamond REALLY in the rough, if you will....

At this point in my Nightlifetime, there have been no comparisons to this closet sized bar with bathtub chilled beer and to be quite frank, I wouldn't want there to be another one. It's perfect in its own little shack-ish way, a pub right out of England (even though I believe the owner is from Ireland), with the quirkiest of the quirks, and all the entertainment a live Saturday night could really need. People are usually apprehensive to its size and forced intimacy, but get them the Blue Chimay and they'll warm up to their neighbors pretty quick.

Fun Times... 4 Stars!
author: Morgan S.

description:
Is it a good thing that a bar has rules? I guess I always thought that rules and bars don't mix. Anyways, two of the rules are as follows: 1) no cell phones, and 2) always give up your seat if a lady enters the bar. I guess those aren't too bad.

The real appeal (or draw) of this bar is it's size. Typically bigger is better, but when it comes to a bar where you actually want to get to know those around you and have a conversation, smaller does the trick.  This place is probably 18 ft. by 6 ft. and is the smallest bar in SF (if not the world.) Enjoy a Chimay and talk with your neighbor.
author: Dave L.

description:
See, bigger isn't always better.  

The coziest, most chill, funnest, and friendliest bar in Northern California.  Make that the US.  The hell with it, the universe!  James should be given a medal from the city and one of those large ceremonious keys for establishing a fun and friendly bar.  Socializing is mandatory and welcome, and there's none of that lame "Standing around looking bored while trying to find cute guys" Marina bs.  

This is my favorite bar in the city by far!
author: Ria D.

description:
This place is tiny but always friendly.  Don't go there if you want a private conversation with a date.  Good selection of beers, and I remember having a cheese plate with several european style cheeses.  

Awesome neighborhood bar.
author: Kurt L.

description:
Exceptional service by the Master of the pub, James. 

Best place to grab a drink, eat a cheese plate, and have a little conversation in the city. Hands down.

Truly a hole in the wall place, the Black Horse usually has one cask of ale on tap and a few tasty bottled beer. The Chimay is a great choice.

The clientelle are mostly locals, friendly, and it's easy to get a conversation going with most of them. 

Highly recommended!
author: Ben R.

description:
Really chill teeny tiny bar. The boys had fun here while the girls got Mani Pedi's next door. Plus, plus for being super dog friendly. 
 Later on we joined them for some Chimay, "white grape juice" and dice. Black Horse is full of character and great people.
author: Douggers M.

description:
This would be my local watering hole if I only lived closer. The bar tenders are courteous and try to make room for everyone in this comfy hole-in-the-wall. 

I was waiting for a friend to meet me here and it was easy enough to strike up a conversation with the other patrons while I waited (or you could feel free to not chat as well - there didn't seem to be a lot of pressure either way). At one point in the evening I think there were roughly 30 or 40 people crammed into the tiny space. Somehow it worked. :)

The beer selection is great (more "worldly" options), the atmosphere is grandma's kitchen/english pub/diner counter and the patrons are as varied as the city.
author: Becky B.

description:
So happy I came here!  My girlfriend lives right across the street, so this is her and her man's neighborhood bar.  

First off:  it's small.  Very small.  Small as in I'm sitting on a bar stool, and someone squeezes by and their crotch is on my knee small.  Good thing I don't have a problem with crotch on the knee (kidding).  Shake it off, Sarah!  So, they only serve beer.  And, yeah, it's all in an old fashioned style bathtub behind the bar.  We had Chimays.  The bartender/owner is super nice and friendly.  

Ask to see the Black Horse calendar.  They have one for guys and one for girls.  Hilarious!  Each Man of the Month or Woman of the Month is a customer/regular... in sexy outfits.  Beyond classic.  

They also have this "buzzing" game.  Ask to play it, they'll get it off the shelf for you and show you how to play.  I love drinking and playing games- we need more bars like that.  

All in all, a really fun bar- filled with regulars and people just down to have a good time.
author: Sarah F.

description:
I was considering writing a nasty horrible review of the place but that would not be truthful. This is one of my all time favorite places from when it is packed or empty. 
You get the feeling that your all in this together...
author: Marcus R.

description: My friend introduced to me this place one St. Patties. The bartender was dressed as the pope, served bottled beer from a bathtub behind the bar, and had a spray bottle of Jameson .. or maybe that was just from the clientele. I've been back there since, and everybody is always friendly, and its a great place to knock back the beer.   The place is TINY though, so don't bring a crowd.
author: Daniel W.

description: Great local hangout.  Love their Mateveza beer.  Great place with wonderful staff.  The bartender even made treats for the Friday night crowd.
author: Tommy B.

description:
This is an awesome, TEENY-tiny, old school bar sporting old school house rules, including no talking on cell phones (though texting I believe is allowed - if not I was seriously breaking this one).  The beer is on ice behind the bar in an old claw-foot bathtub (insert "AWESOME!" here), and while they claim that they have fit 50 people, I challenge that no more than 25 can squeeze in - and that would be like 25 sardines in a well-packed can.  If you're claustrophobic, that's ok - you too can enjoy this fabulous establishment!  Just come during daylight hours - as I've heard it doesn't draw as much of a crowd.  The bartender (and co-owner) James was sweet as can be - and introduces himself to all of his customers, making it a point to remember their names for future visits.  But the *best* part?!  One of the house rules is that men must offer up their seats to ladies.  LOVE IT!  Too many men show a serious lack of chivalry... and while many should have learned this a long time ago, James proves that it's never too late to educate on proper etiquette.  

And for all of you guys who aren't so pleased with having to offer up your seat, think of if this way:  it's a fantastic way to strike up a conversation with the dashing brunette across the bar.  And by across the bar, I do mean four feet away.

Fantastic place... I'll surely be returning.
author: Whitney H.

description: The worse kept secret in San Francisco. The Black Horse is actually a deli, but come sundown, the coolest bartender in the planets rolls out a porcelain tub of alcoholic riches. James and his tiny nook of a bar is the happiest place to grab a beer!
author: Rey G.

description: I feel like this eeety beeety bar is made for eeety beeety people; not for the 10+ burly men and women that were crammed in here on a Friday night. Some how it all works because everyone who goes here seems to "get it." After about 10 minutes of paralyzing claustrophobia, I realized that it wasn't so bad. So what if the guy next to me was so close he might as well be shacked up in bed with me. So what if I could smell the beer on his breath and the girl next to me had her purse resting in my lap. So what if I didn't have an inch of space to stretch my limbs. I had a beer in my hand and a smile on my face.... and somehow as the evening went on, I got it.
author: Julia N.

description:
Scott, the friendly bartender here emphatically announced to me "You have found the best bar in San Francisco".

And I wholeheartedly agree. Great things come in small sizes and this is a case in point. Super highly recommended.
author: sunny m.

description:
Long on regular patrons, cool owner and good bartenders.

Short on high prices and attitude.

This is a must visit for any bar creature.  Highly recommend.
author: The P.

description: Had a great night in there. It may be small but that's it's secret weapon... great place for drunken chit-chats.
author: Ian D.

description:
the black horse seats about 12 and holds about 30.  they have a reasonable selection of beer and the tight quarters impose a kind of forced mingling...excuse me...pardon me...sorry, i didn't mean to touch you there...that's not my hand...oh my...really?...ok well...nice to meet you.

play darts you'll have the added challenge of lofting your dart over about 4 people so please play only if you are good...really good.

this place also has a set of house rules posted on the walls, for example, ladies get priority for the bar stools.  now this sounds very proper and chivalrous, but i suspect its just a way for the bartenders to get more action...as if they need any help...

anyway, a nice cozy pub with a neighborhood feel if you happen to be in, well, the neighborhood.

cheers!
author: eric g.

description: I don't know how to give this place a positive enough review. My girlfriend and I were walking towards the waterfront for New Years fireworks about 9p, when a gentleman stepped out from the bar and encouraged us to come in. We started talking to people and met a bike mechanic, a bunch of Austrian tourists, along with a few other couples. We had enough fun that we called my parents who joined us after their New Years party ended. We left at closing and I gave a $100 tip for the best bar experience I've had in memory.
author: Cameron K.

description: tiny. great conversations with strangers. chimay. james is cool. i'll be back. totally wasted but i do remember asking something about a cheese plate lol, that was interesting.
author: Abigail W.

description:
This is a great little spot where they serve up beer from a bath tub (don't worry, it's bottled) and all the patrons and bartenders are friendly as can be.  

Somewhere between the Marina and Russian Hill, this place is not what one would expect after visiting other bars in the area.  There are no frat boys or hair extensions here.  

They won my heart when last time I came they offered me not 1 but 3 slices of pizza to accompany my brew.  Black Horse London . . . you had me at hello.
author: Brenna C.

description: I can't believe this bar has as good a rating as is reflected.  It's small and the 4 or 5 people that can sit in there are all weird...not weird as in unique, or weird as in "not Marina," weird as in just plain weird.
author: elizabeth b.

description:
Not for the claustrophobic or friendliphobic...
Everything (good)  they say about this place is true. It's tiny, they only serve beer and James is an outstanding people person and bartender.  Great place to pass the time, meet some people, and perhaps play DICE!!!  This is NOT a place for posing, dressing up or being pretentious.
author: Priscilla C.

description: As a small person, I appreciate little spaces more than average person, and I loved this place. I've walked by this bar more times than I can count and finally last Thursday I stopped in. Six types of beer, including white and blue Chimay, and everything was $5 or under. And they have cheese platters. The best part was that everyone in the bar was friendly- everyone chatted with each other, and had great conversations. I haven't experienced that in a bar in San Francisco the first time you walk in. It was simply wonderful. I look forward to being on a first-name basis with the regulars.
author: Noelle Q.

description: I sat on one of 10 stools; leaned back against the 'far' wall with my feet on the bar.  It's comfy being a drunk fool in such intimate confines.
author: Jake H.

description: Fantastic spot.  Smaller than my old studio apartment, but HUGE in terms of good times, great bartenders and fun.  Excellent beer list, but only beer available.  Come by if you want to meet random people, chat with your bartender, and pretend you're at a small house party.
author: Jordan B.

description: The first time i visited SFO i was treated to what my friend called the smallest bar in town.  To tell you the truth that didn't really excite me.  But when we got there and he proved to be truthful i was very pleased.  the bar had some nice beers to offer all served ice cold out of a bathtub full of ice behind the bar.  Most recently in SFO on my first day out at night i asked if we could go back to that really small bar.  I was so happy to learn that they were serving Mateveza beer.  its very exclusive to the west coast and have been hoping to have some since i was last in portland OR.  We were able to talk with james the barkeep more because the place was pretty much empty and he was great.  no matter who showed up that night, local or stranger he was pleasant and accommodating.  i recommend this bar to anyone who likes to see the bars most people don't go to in SFO.
author: Darreck R.

description:
Absolutely love this place, I honestly can not think of another bar in the city I'd rather go to for a non-specific purpose. No, you won't be packed into a bar with a bunch of frat guys and sorority chicks, no you won't be slipping from dark corner to hardcore-music filled dark corner among tattooed peeps, and no you won't be dancing like an idiot to house techno (who even likes that crap anyway?). 

What you get here is perfect: A tiny place, friendly people, good beer. Done. 

Can't be beat.
author: John E.

description: At first I thought this bar must be cool because it is always packed with people flowing out of the doors. At the same time, I never wanted to go because it was always so packed. Yesterday, I went and it was heaven. Great beer selection, chill bartender, good patrons, and that old magical London feel that I so miss. I think that fact that it's maybe 8 feet by 12 feet may now be one of the best parts- only cool kids will keep coming.
author: Alicia J.

description: Yes, it is tiny, but everything it does is done perfectly.  It is a great small pub.
author: Amme P.

description: The size of a shoe-box... it MIGHT hold 20 people on a good day.  But the excellent selection of English beer and the friendly bartenders make it worth cramming yourself in here.  And even when it feels "crowded," there still aren't enough people to drown out your voice, so it's pretty easy to have a conversation.
author: Andrew E.

description:
i loved this place!! went here on a whim with my cousin and although i usually play hermit after work, she's visiting from out of town, so i forced my lazy ass to get up and go out. boy am i glad that i did!! this is a great little neighborhood bar, and i'm not joking about little, the place seats only about 10 people. 

we walked in and i felt like we were walking in on a small private party where everyone knew each other, but we were instantly welcomed. they only have about 5 beers, but they apparently rotate them every few months. the atmosphere is really chill and everyone is friendly with each other, although most people do know each other. but it's a great place to just unwind after work or before heading out for a big night. 

james, the owner was really friendly. introduced himself and spent a little time talking to us. told us they'd ordered pizza and that if we were hungry to just go ahead and grab a couple slices at the end of the bar. kim, the girl who was working the bar offered home-made rice krispy treats. we had a choice of plain and coconut/cranberry ones. apparently she bakes every tuesday!! at least 2 guys, who i assume were regulars, stopped by, grabbed the tasty treats, said hello and left. 

i'll definitely be back and can't wait to become a 'regular' as well. oh, and if you stop by, ask to see 'the men of the black horse 2008 calendar' it's hilarious!!!
author: Angela W.

description:
awesome things about the black horse:

a) beer only. and it comes from a bucket.
b) 12 seats
c) everyone has to get up when you have to pee
d) owned by people who love the bar
e) there's no space for all of those douchebags who fill up other bars
author: James K.

description:
If I died and did go to heaven, it would be the Black Horse Pun and Deli.

Small, small, small bar is off the beaten Union St. path and is a complete delight. They only serve beers, such as Bombardier, Chimay, and usually have a cask conditioned keg and a cider on "tap". Tap either being what I assume is a pneumatic keg and a antique tub. How can you not love that.

What makes this place awesome is the bartenders, especially the owner James and the people who frequent this small place. Place is full of great conversations, bring a friend or make some here. 

There are some rules, abide by them. Like put your cell phone on vibrate and shove it in your pants, purse or leave it at home. And be chivalrous with your stool. Such a small place I never knew there was a bathroom, always run across the street to the gas station. And they do have food here, a great cheese plate.
author: David B.

description:
I like this place. 

Nothing on tap the night I went in, just various beers in cans and bottles and really friendly folks inside. The bathtub full of beer completes the sensation of crowding into a bathroom with six friends to talk and drink. 

The owner and bartendress were extreremely friendly and warm. I'll definitely return.
author: Gym W.

description: I went here for the first time the other night.  It was really fun.  There was not much room there, but it was really fun nonetheless.  They have really good specials.  They only serve beer as far as I could tell.  It was really fun though.  It was a nice local bar and a nice place to meet locals.  I went there with my brother and two of his friends that I just met and we had a fun time.  They have a bunch of cool games and such there.  They also have a set of rules there that was really nice as well.  No talking on the cell phone, give your seats up to ladies if you are guys when they walk in etc... People there were really friendly and we met a lot of people at the bar and hung out with them at the bar as well.  The bartender seemed friendly enough and carries on full conversations with you as well.
author: James J.

description: I don't go drinking anymore as I am a family man but ever once in a while I go for a beer with a friend and this place is the number place I go. The Black Horse is the size of a rich women's closet except instead of shose if full of good people and great beer. The owners and bartenders love what they do, serving great beer and talking with interesting and fun people. They usually only have one beer on tap, the speciality of the day and/or week and then a selection of bottle beer. Most all is from aboard, my favorite is Chimay. The owners have standing rule that if a lady/s come into the bar the men have to give up their sits, so ladies you will always have somewhere to sit.  Love this place, not a pick up bar, just a good place to enjoy a cold one and converstation.
author: Alec D.

description: Go. James and JJ, the owners, make this little spot the best bar in the world. The blackboard with the ~6 beers offered that night never steer wrong. I usually stick with a chimay blue, but never more than 3. Never more than 3. Go. Support these guys, all of them, infront of the bar and behind. This place is the best gathering of people I have ever met. I loved working there the short months that I got to, go back whenever possible.
author: Ian M.

description: Been to the BHLD a few times since moving to the area.  While the selection is limited due to the purchasing location, they have good prices for a pint or two whenever you're around.  But more importantly, the people make this place - it always has a group of people ready with a story or some good conversation.  Not to mention James is a pretty laid back guy so things run well.  Last prop - NO CELL PHONES IN THE BAR!  Best idea in the world given the size of this pint-sized brewhouse.  Keep it up - I'm going back.
author: Mark J.

description: I barely noticed the change of ownership that took place more than two years ago (it was also a bar).  The selection of beer shows that they care about the details as does the Ploughman's Platter.  The bartender and proprietor is a doll.  I can see myself going back for sure.  It's only dinged one star because of an annoying group of patrons and I can see that being a problem.  What can I say?  I have a low tolerence for such things.  That's why I go out early.  That, and I am getting old.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Going to the Black Horse is like showing up to a party where you know a few people and then like totally make best friends with all of their friends. I am going back now ALL the time. They have great cask ale (purportedly difficult to find in the city, though I admit I have never really tried) and really, really beyond friendly service. I honestly felt like I was at a friend's house.
author: Sahra H.

description: Chimay makes you go heeeey!! Well at least it has that affect on us. lol ...Absolutely love this bar. James and Kris are fricken awesome. Went in months back for the first time, and now try to make a stop by there every time I'm in the City. My friend had her "quitting party" there, it was hilarious trying to stuff our crowd and the rest of the patrons into this place.  I love that the guys remember names/friends etc. It's an interesting journey trying to get to the bathroom, but worth it. You never know what cuteness you get to snuggle next to while waiting for your turn.
author: Erica A.

description: While there couldn't be a worse fit for the saying "good for groups," I'd imagine the Black Horse Pub is one of the best places to grab a beer with one or two other people. I wouldn't know this first hand of course, since we tried coming here with a decent sized group, but somehow we all crammed in (with a bit of spillage onto the sidewalk at times). But all in all, it makes for a very intimate pub experience that you can't find anywhere else in the city. The bathtub behind the bar and cheese plates served with drinks make for a nice touch.  If I lived closer I would definitely stop in more often.
author: C P.

description: Perfect spot for a beer on a Friday afternoon!  Very small space so prepare to get to know your neighbor :)  If they served wine, I may never leave.
author: Kim F.

description: Quite the neighborhood bar. There is no scene whatsoever, just good beer, good people and a great cheese plate. Its a great place to take friends or to hang out and meet a new one. James is the man, he will go out of his way to make sure you are having a good time and drinking more of his fine beers. The place is tiny so you better be ready to make nice with your neighbor.
author: Joe A.

description: I had a couple of friends in town and we were looking for a nice low-key bar to watch the Sunday Night football game.  I knew this place was right down the street from my apt, so I decided to check it out.  When we got there it was so small that we were a little hesitant that it would be the right place to go.  One of the other bar patrons that was outside smoking started chatting with us while we were outside being indecisive and he convinced that we should stop in and have at least one beer.  Glad I did.  The beer selection was small, but solid.  The bartender was very friendly in a genuine kind of way.  It was just a lot different from most bars where everyone is kind of in their own world, here everyone was talking to each other even though there seemed to be at least 4 separate groups of people.  I would have given 5 stars if there was actually enough room for the dart board.  Also, I wouldn't mind a slightly larger selection of beer.
author: Ted G.

description: This place was easily AS ambient as any pub in England - and I didn't believe the whole "smallest pub in North America" thing until I walked in.  Very cozy - went twice and felt like family.  Apparently the Ploughman's Platter is fantastic, good selection of cheese, onion, etc.  My aunt tried it (without me) and raved.  The owner is a hoot.  Ask him why he's allowed to call it a "pub".
author: Catherine F.

description: On a fun-per-square-foot basis, the Black Horse could be one of the coolest bars in San Francisco. Great vibe, nice staff, good beer. (Oy that Chimay!) I feel like keeping my review short is a bit, well, appropos here.
author: Aaron L.

description: It's a bit snug (READ tiny!) but the first time I walked in here they gave us FREE PIZZA. They have a very small selection of beers but their choices are FANTASTIC. They have excellent taste in beers, and they're not only British beers, but also Austrian and German beers. They also had fun games, one being an electrocution one. It's great fun when you're drunk. The bartenders are super nice, they'd have to be cause this place seriously has only room for maybe 20-30 people MAX  (I think even 30 is pushing it).  They always have food because they're a food and beer/wine establishment. They don't have a whole lot of beers on tap, but what they sell is pretty tasty on it's own, especially if you're a beer connoseiur.
author: Gina R.

description: Small but with the greatest beer and cheese platter!!  Clock in and get a pint!
author: George M.

description: I like this bar a lot, haven't been in awhile....but we used to ride bikes over to the Black Horse and there were always a bunch of crusty old timers. Love that. Also any bar that is that small makes me feel big and there's no other feeling like it!
author: Colleen B.

description: Great place!  I had my birthday party here last year and I think we packed in about 25 people!  My roommate at the time was even allowed to bartend the event!  Really friendly barstaff and regulars.
author: Paul D.

description: I've been meaning to have a  drink here for years, but don't find myself in the neighborhhod much any more. We had a few minutes to kill while we waited for our reservation up the street, so we came here. It's a tiny place but we managed to get some of the last seats in the place. "King" James was made us welcome. I't's a freindly place with good music, not loud and easy to scialize. We only had time for one, but I'll be back. It's on of the better / places on that side of town.
author: Sleepy T.

description: Weird, odd and unusual are the first words that enter my mind after leaving this place. $5 for your choice of 5 different bottles of beers served out of a bathtub. Apparently the cask ale has been out for more than 6 months and they don't know when it can be filled again. I suggested Rogue as a supplier, but apparently they don't deliver. The people were overly friendly, but maybe I just wasn't drunk enough...
author: Nicolas H.
