description: This place is great, small, but great. I was told an amazing story of a game of darts from the doorway that ending up with a "holy" pewter mug!!
author: Todd C.

description: This bar is small but great things do come in small packages... apparently... anyway, good conversation, reasonably priced beer, and the size of the bar + the way it is laid out, forces all patrons to get to know one another... a breathe of fresh air in a city that tends to get really clicky and forget to interact with people outside of their comfort level.
author: Stephen B.

description: With a bar that seats less than 4, a killer cheese plate, and some of the only "true" brittish cask ale in the city, the Black Horse is a neighborhood local gem.
author: Dave M.

description: It was an itsy bitsy teenie weenie... bar that is. But what a hell of a bar it was. Just keep in mind that there are only about 10 or so barstools  and no other table seating. Drinks? I was a happy little monkey when I found out that they served cider (not on tap). The beer on tap was nice as well. As mentioned previously, the cheese plate rawks.
author: Christie A.

description: This is a great neighborhood bar. Although small, this place is amazing. No more than 20 people can fit inside but the crowd is excellent. The owner introduces himself and keeps everyone's tab on a yellow lined paper.  They serve only a few different kinds of imported bottled beer out of a bath tub but who can complain about Krusovice.
author: elissa w.

description: I used to go to this bar daily on my way home when I lived in SF.  My apartment was near Green and Laguna and I hated my neighborhood, except for this gem and a few other dingy treasures in the Marina.  It has been a long time, but you used to be able to smoke inside because it was a sole proprietor, i.e. no employees.  I haven't been back in years, but given the amazing comments, I don't think much has changed, which is a good thing. Any time you have a keg chilling in ice in a big, old clawfoot bathtub, you know you're in the right place.
author: Victor T.

description:
This is pretty much what every bar should strive to be: a local watering hole with character, where the bartender engages the whole bar  (that is, all 10 patrons that can fit) in lively conversation, and where cool, delicious, obscure imported beers are served on a daily basis.

Four stars PLUS a bonus star for serving a great cheese and salami platter!!  (To comply with local laws requiring this joint to be a "deli", not a "bar.").

Oh yeah, and there's a dart board.
author: Chris F.

description: Can't believe I never wrote a review for the Black Horse... it's the best bar in the city.  Everything has already been said here: James is the best, it's cozy, love the courtesy rules, great beer selection, and just a great place to have a good beer.  A must-visit.
author: Bob A.

description: Don't you love when you get so drunk that you don't remember shit......and you friends have to give you a play by play on all the retarded things that you did.....maybe I really am retarded....anyways.....I love this place!
author: tom h.

description: One word..Chimay! and more words...best atmosphere ever! quaintest set up I have seen in the city...and when i say quaint, i mean tiny with tons of character and charm. be prepared to make friends with everyone in the bar within 10 minutes of getting in there....you pretty much have no choice since you are all on top of each other..literally.  tuesdays are the best since they give out pizza and the nice bar tender makes baked goods for everyone! james(the owner) is hilarious and ready to be your best friend right away. perfect if you want the whole cheers scenario where everyone knows your name, what kind of drink you want, etc. and if you are even in the mood to show up by yourself looking like a scrub after a long day!
author: Lauren H.

description:
Let me just get this out of the way to begin with. Yes gentleman, size matters! If you have heard that it doesn't please check your references again. They may be faulty. There are only a couple reasons why a woman would say that to you: 1. You have been with this girl for some time, possibly dating/ possibly marriage. She is not saying that because she is trying to make you feel better about yourself, although if she is nice she is sparing your feelings. It is quite the opposite, she is saying it because she is making herself feel better that she has stuck with a guy of your stature for this long. (*wink) 2. You are hooking up and in order for her to avoid your pitiful inadequacies, self esteem issues, or a night of hugging her pillow as she listens to you in the fetal position sobbing like a 4 yr old school boy in the corner, she says it doesn't matter. 3. Or lastly, regardless of what happened between the two of you, she is going to tease you to no end, behind your back and to your co-workers, once you are no longer intimate. 

In the Know: Now with that said, take everything I just said and disregard it (for a moment). At the Blackhorse it is all about size, and trust me when I say, the smaller the better! I can count the maximum occupancy on my 'lil fingers and toes, and that includes standing room. The bar divides the space in half, roughly 2-3ish feet on either side. Behind the bar is a small (do I even need to say that if the whole thing is small?) service station, a place to make a delicious cheese platter and/or a samich (sandwich for all those properly edumakated folks), and of course an old school bath tub filled with cans or a keg. The decor is what you would expect to find at any local London pub, including but not limited to pictures of London, beer posters, hanging steins and my personal favorite "Rules of Behavior." Now I feel as though these rules should just be common knowledge for any bar but apparently the good ol' days of male chivalry (you must give your seat to a lady if she doesn't have one) and female courtesy (ladies no one wants to hear what you have to say on your cell phone, especially about the guy you met outside your apartment at 3 in the morning and now you regret letting him know where you live because at any second he could turn into a stalker so you have to constantly keep your eye out every time you walk around your hood) have completely been ignored. Blackhorse, way to make us face our issues with claustrophobia and behavioural patterns all in one swoop. That is why we (the 'we' refers to me and my other personality) totally heart you! 

Behind the Bar: My favorite thing about going to certain bars is having a friend be a bartender. On top of receiving cheap to free drinks all night, they always give me the honest, inside scoop on what works and what makes them secretly want to burn the establishment down. More often than not they want to do the later but that generally goes hand-and-and with hating the owners of the place or knowing that they are working for people that are dumber than they are and resent them or the bar even more. (*not that that has ever happened to me...um....ya....) I am very happy to report that neither of those are an issue at this place. My friend loves the owner and loves the small space he works in. So really there are no negatives for this section. (might actually be a first!) *I should mention that the one thing quite literally behind the bar is the Black Horse calendar. People, if for nothing else, please take a gander at this. It could possibly be the hottest thing I have ever seen. 

Who is Who: This bar might be considered located in the Marina, but it is far from a Marina crowd. (Thank god!) The couple times I have been there the patrons are nothing but laid back people that just want to enjoy a cozy spot with some friends. I might go as far as to say this could be one of the best bars in the city. I wouldn't do that though because I am a cynical and selfish. I mean if you can only fit 20ish people in this bar, why the heck would I want to tell the masses to go there?
author: Sheyna G.

description:
This place is the friendliest bar, great crowd and the nicest bartender in the city.

If you haven't been check it out.
author: lindsay d.

description:
This is the Cheers bar you've been waiting for. 

When we're craving a good dinner with better company, we'll go and enjoy a Chimay and a cheese plate that cannot be beat. 

The best part about the bar is the friendly bartenders and the clientele-we've met many good friends at the Horse.

We love you James!
author: Lindsay B.

description: Third time was just as fun as the first two.  Next time you go and Scott is bartending ask for SCOTTGUNS!!!!   He'll know what to do.  This place is awsome!
author: BIG B.

description: There is nothing better to do on a chill Friday night than stop in and hang out with your local friends and have some beers out of a bathtub. The biggest reason to go to this place though...Jaime...the best bartender around. She makes the whole experience that much better!
author: Ilya F.

description: It's hard to find places with a true pub feel but the Black Horse has it!  Even though this place is the size of your bathroom it has more character than most bars you will encounter.  If you don't like small places or socializing with your fellow pub patrons then you may not like this place.  I'd suggested going to this place with limited people and planning on making some new friends (the whole bar can probably only fit 20 people).
author: Justin R.

description: Countless times I have walked past the Black Horse Pub, the smallest bar in San Francisco- sometimes during the day, and sometimes at night when I see just how crowded and intimate it can get. And countless times I've said to myself, I should really check it out- yet I never did....until tonight. And thank god I did otherwise I would be missing out on one of the city's best kept secrets- a gem of a bar with friendly staff and a jovial ambiance. People are friendly, and due to the close proximity of you and your beer drinking neighbors, you can be sure you'll strike up a conversation with a stranger at some point during the evening. I had the Belgian Chimay, served in a glass fit for an ice cream sundae. The bartender reached into a bathtub filled with beer bottles- note they don't serve from a tap- to fish out the desired brew. The beer was served cold, and although it was colder than possible outside (this is San Francisco summer for you) the nearly claustrophobic nature of this establishment kept me warm. And claustrophobic isn't necessarily a bad thing here either. It's just pleasantly packed (and with friendly people, no doubt). Yes pleasantly packed, not packed like you find on the 30 or 45 buses going past Chinatown, but I digress. I had the feeling I had entered someones home (completely with pizza and laundry service, no kidding!) as charming knick knacks lined the walls. Even the bathroom was kept incredibly orderly for such a bustling pub. All in all, this is a wonderful and warm environment in which to enjoy a variety of beers. I highly recommend it over the more traditional Marina establishments.
author: Kate A.

description: Finding a place like this is why I am addicted to yelping.  I am visiting the city for a conference and I wanted to find some local flavor and stay away from the tourist traps.  I definitely found a diamond in the rough in Black Horse.  Perhaps the smallest bar I've been in, and I have been in some small bars.  Completely packed nuts to butts yet completely charming.   Jaimie was the bartender that night and made me feel right at home.  Met many locals which is what I was looking for.  Made friends with James who gave me the first tri-tip sandwich he made (some guy made it and brought it by to share!) which I thought was a kind gesture since I was a guest.  Someone also came by with a cup of what I think was an English stew of some sort.  I felt like I was part of the family!  Before I left I asked for a water and it was poured in a Radeberger Pilsner mug which was so cool looking I asked if I could buy it for my bar glass collection and as a souvenir of the place.  James gave it to me :)  I am so glad that I came here.  I will make it a point to visit every time I am in SF.
author: Juliana M.

description: i think this is the tiniest bar in SF. small but a good time. friendly bartender. a good place if you actually want to have a conversation.
author: Michelle I.

description: This is probably one of the best bars in the entire city.  It's one of those neighborhood gems that is loaded on charm.  A tiny bar, which lend itself well to an intimate experience with the locals.  Well worth checking out, but be warned that they only take cash and as far as I know only serve beer.
author: Debbie M.

description: i got ridiculously drunk here last night, the beer keeps flowing and they laugh at you when you leave.  well maybe they just laugh at me.
author: Lindsay T.

description: niiiice. cozy spot with good beer and friendly patrons. you kind of have to be in the mood to sit down and shoot the shit in order to come into this place, because you'll be in close quarters with everyone there. very neighborhoody feel, a definite spot for socializing with your brew.
author: Tom H.

description: This place is about great beer and good conversation. No cell phones, no TV, no frills. The patrons are generally super friendly and the bartenders are always welcoming. If I was new to SF, hitting the town solo, this is the first place I'd stop by.
author: K W.

description: Its so small that they can completely control not only the atmosphere but the interaction between people. They do a great job at making sure the personality of the place transcends one on one conversations. It a really unique cool place. We walked in not knowing anything about the place, met a bunch of east coast people and felt like we had been coming there for years. Highly recommended!!!
author: dc h.

description: This London-styled pub is one of the best places to hang out. The small capacity space (everyone has to get up when you have to pee)makes it hard not to make friends. And the bartender makes this pub even better. He makes sure that the Black Horse Tenets are followed. Patrons look forward to the rotating selection of European imported beers including Chimay, Bombardier and Stiegl to name a few. The menu is limited to a cheese plate and a sandwich but that isn't what people come here for. If you are looking for the perfect cozy neighborhood bar, this is it.
author: Alexander L.

description: This has been one of my very favorite bars in SF for the last ten years.  It is like drinking in a phone booth, so you quickly get to know everybody in the place.  Very chill vibe.  Extra bonus points for the no-cell phone rule that keep the place douchebag free.
author: Mike C.

best pub hands down.
james and blue.
author: m b.

description: The concept is pretty cool and the bartender was equally cool, but upon entering, I knew I had to get the hell out of there immediately. Perhaps I went on the wrong night, but after reading all these reviews I was under the impression that everyone talked to everyone, were eager to meet new people, etc. so I waltzed in by myself. Turned out, everyone inside knew each other (not sure if a large group of people went there together or what) and kind of just looked at me like I was a weirdo for going by myself. I felt very uncomfortable and awkward. Also, one of the bar's "rules" is to not butt in on others' conversations unless invited, so I didn't want to just jump in and start laughing along out of nowhere with people. I decided to stick it out for a second beer thinking that maybe I just needed to give it a chance but I just wanted to get out of there the whole time. I'm a social, nice guy so it's not like I was just some freak or some douche walking in. Again, no fault of the bartender or the bar itself, maybe the people on that particular night just sucked. The beer selection wasn't anything outstanding, but it was decent. I did like the atmosphere though and I could totally see how it could be a fun place. If I went again, I would definitely go with someone so as to not feel like an alien.
